TALK.START.PARA: —I have to inform the Senate that the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) is ill and is likely to be absent for some weeks. The Minister for Communications (Mr N . A. Brown) will act as Attorney-General until Senator Durack returns to duty. For the period of Senator Durack's absence, Senator Chaney will represent the Acting Attorney-General in this chamber; Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle will represent the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Hodges); and Senator Messner will represent the Minister for Defence (Mr Sinclair) and the Minister for Defence Support (Mr Viner).

—by leave-On behalf of the Opposition, I express our regret at hearing of Senator Durack's illness. I think it is fair to say that, quite apart from periods of the hurly-burly of debate, which have been quite considerable in this chamber in the past week or two and in which Senator Durack has been in the eye of the storm, if I can put it in those terms, most Opposition members regard him as a friend and a respected colleague. There are a lot of theories about the causes of illnesses of this kind. Perhaps sometimes we had a lot of annoyance with Senator Durack because he seemed such an unflappable personality. It is one of the strange ironies that that does not seem to have been the case. We take the opportunity to wish him a speedy recovery and a quick return to the chamber.

—by leave-My party and I have already been in direct communication with Senator Durack and his family and we are hoping for his speedy recovery. We are delighted to know that apparently the attack was a mild one. Having had some intimate knowledge of such attacks, I am quite sure that, if Senator Durack follows the advice of the wonderful people at the Royal Canberra Hospital and of his colleagues and takes things easily, he will return to the fray within a relatively short time. I do not suggest that he will be fit enough or stupid enough to return to the vigours of Australian Rules football after a year, but let me reassure him that, in respect of the kind of attack that he has had, he is capable of a complete recovery. And we wish him just that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: ROBERTSON

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Georges, I present the following petition from 69 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

1. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognise that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognise that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognise that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects, namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Great Barrier Reef Marine Park
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
The Great Barrier Reef is unique and is included on the World Heritage List.

Although the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act was to create a marine park to provide for the proper protection and management of The Reef, only 14 per cent of the total area defined in this Act as the Great Barrier Reef Region has been declared marine park.
The only insurance against an oil drilling blowout in Reef waters is to prohibit oil drilling in the Region and its vicinity.
This can only be effected by declaring the whole area of the Region a marine park under the above legislation.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to take action to hold a referendum together with the next Federal Elections on the question that:

The entire area of the Great Barrier Reef and its surrounding waters, defined as the Great Barrier Reef Region in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, as amended 1978, be immediately declared a marine park under the provisions of that Act.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 575 citizens) and Primmer (from 494 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned about the high and increasing rate of divorce and family breakdown, convinced that the Family Law Act has weakened marriage by making divorce a trivial matter, the present Act paying scant regard to its own definition of marriage as a life-long union; and believing that the legal bond of marriage should be strengthened.
Humbly petition for the Family Law Act and Marriage Act to be amended in order to:
(1) Reject any moves towards divorce by post;
(2) Restore the former prohibition of marriages between close relatives by blood or by marriage;
(3) Protect the rights and welfare of aggrieved partners of a marriage who are threatened with being divorced against their will;
(4) Ensure that in divorce judgments paramount attention be given to whatever course will best serve the welfare of dependent children of the marriage;
(5) Encourage counselling towards reconciliation;
(6) Restore objective tests to irretrievable breakdown of marriage in terms of:
(i) intolerable behaviour;
(ii) desertion for two years;
(iii) separation for three years.
And we pray that you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation .
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jessop (from 8 citizens) and McLaren (from 50 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Retail Markets
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Canberra region respectfully showeth:

Whilst mindful that the stallholders of the Fyshwick and Belconnen Markets should own their own businesses, we are of the opinion that the ownership of the markets and controls should be retained as a public utility.

Your petitioners ever pray that the Senate would approve that the questions regarding the markets, including leases of stalls and effective control be referred to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on the A.C.T. with suitable terms of reference approved by the Minister.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the Petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:

That it is clearly apparent that Australian society is becoming more polarised- that the rich at home and abroad are becoming richer profiting from Australia's mineral wealth, whilst pensioners and the disadvantaged, some three million people, are becoming a race apart.

That, of necessity, the Federal Government take action that all Australians share the wealth of their country by the transfer of resources to income security, health care and housing, therefore your petitioners urge that:
1. All pensions and benefits be raised to at least 30 per cent of the National Average Weekly Male Earnings seasonally adjusted.
2. Removal of the means-income test on the Pensioner Health Benefit imposed by Federal legislation 1973. Re-introduction of Medibank in so doing restore all Australians to equality of citizenship.

3. To alleviate Australia's shortage of housing stock within the capacity of people to pay (rental and ownership) the Federal Government inject $200 million into State Housing Authorities, which will, in addition, alleviate unemployment.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of Australia in Parliament assembled.

This petition of certain citizens of Australia concerned with continuing cuts in Federal Government funding of higher education respectfully showeth that the Federal Government cut-backs in funding have:
Made it increasingly difficult for many Australians to contemplate study at a university or college of advanced education;
reduced the resources available to groups with particular needs such as our Aboriginal and Ethnic communities;
seriously jeopardized Australia's ability to keep pace with and contribute to technological developments in a whole range of areas;
reduced the quantity and quality of community education programs offered, especially in rural colleges; and

forced universities and colleges of advanced education to cut back on the numbers of staff available to teach existing courses, endangering the quality of education offering and narrowing the range of courses available.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable Senate:

Ensure that levels of government funding for education are at a level that will enable all Australians to undertake the higher education of their choice regardless of their personal financial circumstances;
provide all students, present and future, with adequate financial assistance by way of allowances and scholarships; and
will make a firm commitment to oppose the re-introduction of any tertiary fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Peter Baume (from 1,633 citizens) and Collard (from 26 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth, do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:
1. Note that legislation establishing plant breeders' rights in other countries has had serious adverse effects, namely:

(a) Virtual monopoly control of seed production has passed into the hands of a few large international corporations seeking to profit from the exclusive rights over plant genetic materials created by such legislation.

(b) The varieties of seeds available have been restricted mainly to hybrids which will not reproduce truly and will not grow without the aid of artificial fertilisers and pesticides, thus maximising corporate profits without regard for the interests of growers and consumers.
(c) The genetic diversity of crops has been eroded, rendering them vulnerable to disease and other environmental threats.

2. Recognise that maintenance of the genetic diversity of plant varieties is crucial to the continued well-being of the Australian nation, and take all necessary steps to preserve and promote such genetic diversity as a public resource and to prevent exclusive control over plant genetic materials from falling into private hands.

3. Defend the vital interests of Australian farmers and gardeners, independent Australian seed companies and their employees, and consumers of Australian farm and garden produce, by rejecting any proposal to legislate for the establishment of plant breeders' rights in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That citizens of South Australia view with great alarm the removal of the Director of the Office of Child Care and fear for the future of that office and the children's services programme which it administers.

We believe the Office of Child Care to be inappropriately placed within the Department of Social Security, where children's services are in competition with welfare services for the aged, disabled, and other such groups.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled , should take every step as necessary to obtain immediate withdrawal of the Office of Child Care from the Department of Social Security and the establishment of a Children's Commission.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

—I ask the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General whether he said on Saturday to the Bendigo Area Conference of the Liberal Party that the Government would not treat people involved in bottom-of-the-harbour tax avoidance schemes as criminals. Is the Minister aware that the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980, which has been referred to by both the Treasurer and the Attorney-General as this Government's answer to bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, prescribes criminal penalties for tax avoiders engaged in such schemes, including fines of $50,000 and gaol terms of five years? Was the Minister's statement designed to reassure potential or real tax avoiders in the Liberal Party or was the Minister saying that the Government does not intend ever to use the provisions of the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act? Is this the reason that not a single prosecution has ever been launched under this Act?

—The seriousness with which the Government viewed the bottom-of- the-harbour schemes was evidenced by the legislation which was put to the Parliament and passed in 1980. It was unusual legislation in that it provided for criminal penalties for people who, by stripping companies, had made those companies unable to pay their tax liabilities. I will re-examine the report in the newspapers about what I said in Bendigo to see whether it bears the interpretation given to it by the Leader of the Opposition. In fact, in Bendigo I was referring to the proposed legislation announced by the Government to deal with vendor shareholders who have sold companies which have subsequently been taken to the bottom of the harbour, as the expression goes. The Government announced some time ago-of course this is a matter which is within the province of the Treasurer but I respond to the question because remarks of mine were reported-that vendor shareholders in those circumstances should have a taxation liability. The point I was making in Bendigo was that the proposed new legislation was new legislation not to impose criminal penalties on vendor shareholders but to impose taxation liabilities on vendor shareholders-a distinction that I am sure will be quite clear to the Leader of the Opposition.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I am pleased with the speed at which the Government has implemented a number of the major recommendations contained in the report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System-the Campbell report. I have had many representations from farmers and rural organisations expressing concern about the availability of finance from traditional lending institutions. Has the Government made a decision on the recommendation to allow the controlled entry of other financial institutions into the banking system? If it has, when will that decision be made public?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry is a very complex document containing numerous recommendations. It has been under study by the Government and a number of responses have already been announced. At this stage I have nothing to say with regard to the matters referred to in the question from Senator Thomas, except that a task force is examining the recommendations and when the Government comes to some further decisions on them it will announce those decisions from time to time. Beyond that I cannot comment on any individual recommendation which is outstanding at present.

—My question is directed to Senator Carrick in his capacity either as Minister representing the Prime Minister or as Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. Is not the Government's action having a detrimental effect on the Australian canned fruit industry and its growers in particular?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think all honourable senators know why the ban was placed. The Australian community has a strong feeling against the aggressive nature of the actions of the USSR in Afghanistan. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, I think, although Senator Chaney may be the responsible Minister. It refers to the draft legislation designed to recover unpaid company taxes from shareholders of companies which evaded these taxes through bottom-of-the-harbour schemes. Is it true that legislation has been submitted to the Government and should be ready for presentation to the Parliament in one or two weeks' time? I ask whether the provisions of that legislation will be based on or will include the principle embodied in the statement made by Senator Peter Rae in the Senate last Thursday, 9 September, which he described as having been made on behalf of the Government in the party room, namely:

QUESTION.PARA: This does not mean that all people who sell companies at higher than their asset backing are at risk. It is only in those cases where the company's tax liabilities were evaded by fraud.

Will the Minister confirm that it is the Government's intention to base the legislation on that principle or to include that principle? Will the Minister confirm this by reference to a particular example? Let us take a family business which is sold by the shareholder couple who wish to retire. Assume that the couple, on the advice of taxation experts, arrange the sale at a favourable price. The couple invest the proceeds in a country cottage and retreat to it to enjoy their retirement. They were totally unaware of the tax liability of the company they sold, which has been avoided through a bottom-of-the-harbour technique. Will the Minister advise whether the Government intends that people who find themselves in the position of such a totally innocent couple will be personally liable for the evaded company tax?

TALK.START.PARA: —Both Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and I are involved in the Government's work in preparing this legislation. It is in the process of preparation and the Government hopes to introduce it as soon as possible. I shall not put a precise time on it because I think that the Treasurer would have the responsibility for doing that, and probably would not wish to do so anyway. As to the precise form of the legislation, I do not think it useful to try to give a detailed explanation of the legislation before its final drafting has been completed. Nor do I think that I should be trying to apply it to examples which honourable senators might raise because they have concerned constituents. The legislation in the broad is aimed at those situations in which people have sold companies on a basis which makes it clear that a current tax liability will not be met-in other words, where there is a situation in which the company has either an actual or a projected tax liability which, when taken into account, would ensure that the return on the sale of the shares was less than what was actually received. It would be most unusual in this place, I think, to try to respond in the manner that has been sought by Senator Chipp on a piece of legislation which has yet to be introduced, and I do not propose to take the answer any further than I have.

—I ask a supplementary question, and in doing so I make the passing comment that if the spirit of Senator Chaney's answer is to be taken for the future Question Time in this place will be reduced to an absolute farce.
—This is a second reading speech.
—I am asking the Minister a supplementary question.

—My point of order is that when an honourable senator seeks to ask a supplementary question he should use that opportunity to ask a supplementary question and not to make gratuitous insults across the chamber.

—If Senator Chaney wants to lead with gratuitous insults in his answer he will get them back every time. I let him know that.

Is the Government contemplating-I trust I can ask the Minister to go that far-in its consideration of this legislation the position of the totally innocent couple who unknowingly sold their shares at a higher price than normal? Will they be covered in this retrospective legislation proposed by the Government?

—Crichton-Browne did that.

—The legislation will not be aiming to catch those circumstances where the market places a value on shares. The legislation will catch those situations where there has been an artificial inflation of the value of shares because, clearly, a tax liability is not going to be met.
—His girl friend was sitting with inside knowledge from Burrill's office.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Walsh is implying that I received inside information from a company office to purchase shares. I ask that he withdraw that. He has said it on a number of occasions. Normally I would put up with his rude, crude, insulting manner, but I think it is about time he was pulled into gear.
—Order! I call the Senate to order.

—On the point of order, Mr President: That is not what I said; what I said was that Senator Crichton-Browne's fiancee was working in the Burrill and Jones geologists'office at the time and she passed on the inside information. But if he finds that offensive I am quite willing to withdraw it.

—Mr President, with respect, it is not a question of whether I find it offensive. It is a question of whether it is contrary to Standing Orders. Senator Walsh is implying that I used information that had been illicitly obtained from a company office.

—Does the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Construction agree with the many western European shipowners who have reported a crisis in their industry and who say that there are idle tonnages at record levels and that the outlook is worsening, with the trouble spreading from tankers to the dry cargo market, notably in surplus bulk carriers and container ships? Have any Australian companies or the Australian National Line sought participation in the development of an efficient, revitalised Australian shipping industry? If new ships are entered on the Australian registry, will the Government ensure that the owners do not expect to be subsidised beyond the measures detailed in the recent Australian shipping policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is clear from recent statements by the Government that policies have recently been adopted by the Government to revitalise Australian shipping with the idea of planning commercial entry into overseas trades. Difficulties are currently being experienced in international shipping, as is acknowledged by Senator Lewis. However, that should not in any way affect the Government's outlook on the longer term questions of revitalisation of the Australian shipping industry. Even in the short term existing market conditions should not prevent Australian shipowners from taking advantage of commercial opportunities wherever and whenever they might arise on world markets. The industry knows that Government assistance will be available and the terms on which it will be given. It will, of course, have to look closely at all aspects of its costs and operations to ensure that it can compete.

ANSWER.PARA: The agreement reached in the industry task force on the Crawford report between shipowners and the maritime unions sets down the basis on which improved industrial and consultative arrangements and reduced manning can be achieved. Australian shipowners and maritime unions working together, therefore, for the advancement of the industry should be able to reach agreement on terms which will ensure the entry of some new Australian ships. However, we do take note of the point in Senator Lewis's question that in fact the industry is looking for only a modest increase of up to 12 ships over three years and, to be eligible for investment incentives, acceptable manning levels must be negotiated with the unions on the new vessels. The points implicit in Senator Lewis's question in connection with the future of Australian shipping, given the conditions that he outlined on the world markets in relation to the shipping industry, are clearly recognised and acknowledged by the Government and are built into the arrangements now outlined.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's electorate talk given on Sunday, 12 September, which contains the following passage:

QUESTION.PARA: It is important for people to know how bottom-of-the-harbour schemes worked, because I do not believe anyone could have taken part in bottom-of-the-harbour schemes without knowing they were wrong.
Is that the Prime Minister's view and the Government's view? Will that view be reflected in any retrospective legislation which has been the subject of earlier questions today?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of the honourable senator's question, I suggest that he await the legislation which will be brought in as soon as possible. I did not hear the Prime Minister's electorate broadcast but I take it that he was referring to a practice in which a shareholder becomes a vendor shareholder by selling his or her shares at a value which has a capital increment, due to the fact that the company tax within the--
—What is all this about? He was talking about bottom-of-the- harbour schemes. There is his statement.

—I am grateful for Senator Button's help. I am reminded of P. G. Wodehouse who dedicated his book to his wife and said: 'Without her valuable assistance this book would have been finished in half the time'. Let me remind Senator Button that, if he wants a factual answer, he should pay attention. If the Prime Minister was referring, as I think he was, to a shareholder who gained a capital increment through the sale of shares because the company tax was not paid, the Prime Minister has expressed the view-that would be a widely held view indeed-that a person being a member of such a company, particularly a proprietary company, could be expected to know that that company has a company debt as one of its debts and could be expected, therefore, to know that the value of the shares, including the capitalised value of the shares, would be greater because the company tax had not been paid. That would be, as I understand the quote from the Prime Minister's speech, a well accepted view in the community that a person would be expected to know that, in such a company, tax was due to be paid and that such a person had gained benefit from it. That being so, what the Prime Minister was saying is that the liability for the debt was there at the time, that in fact there was a liability at the time for company tax and that this is not retrospective application.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General, concerns the automatic declassification of obsolete national security material, as recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the state of progress in this matter, bearing in mind previous assurances by the Attorney-General that the matter was being looked at? Will he also report whether national security classifications have been restricted to national security documents? Can he assure the Senate that there has been a diminution in the over-classification of government material and that national security classifications on Cabinet documents, for instance, are applied only in strict accordance with the security handbook?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that in Senator Durack's sudden absence Senator Hamer was good enough to let me know that he wished to ask this question. I can advise him that the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs recommended, in its report on the Freedom of Information Bill, that a system for automatic declassification of national security documents should be instituted on an administrative basis. The Committee also made a number of other recommendations on classification. The Government's response to these recommendations was that they will be the subject of further study. That was advised to the Senate. It can be found in the Senate Hansard of 11 September 1980, at page 803.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to a question from Senator Hamer on 19 November 1981 on this matter , Senator Durack indicated that the study had not been completed and that, as soon as he had time to do so, he proposed to have further discussions on the matter with officers of his Department. Since then there has been a new executive order issued by the President of the United States of America on the question of automatic declassification. The Senate Committee had the previous presidential order on this matter in mind when it made the recommendations. The question of automatic declassification is still under consideration. I will make further inquiries to find out what progress is being made, particularly in light of the changed situation in the United States.

The instructions on the use of the national security classifications are contained in the protective security handbook. The handbook requires that those classifications be applied to national security information and to Cabinet documents. Instructions as to what constitutes Cabinet documents for this purpose are contained in the Cabinet handbook. I am not, of course, in a position to give an absolute assurance to the Senate that national security classifications are applied only in strict accordance with the national security handbook. The Government has made its intentions clear by the issue of that handbook. I will take the matter up with the Prime Minister to see whether any further instructions are thought to be needed.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ALLIED PRISONERS OF WAR: REPATRIATION BENEFITS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, refers to a statement by him on 17 August detailing advances in repatriation measures, for which he is to be congratulated. I refer in particular to the extension of the free treatment entitlement to certain categories. Already regulation 66 provides that prisoners of war are covered. Could that very small group of Australian citizens who served, for example, in the British forces side by side with Australian troops and who were prisoners of war in Japan also be included in this extension?

—I am not entirely clear as to the provisions of the United Kingdom law in respect of those who served under the conditions outlined by Senator Harradine. However, as I understand it, there would be agency arrangements for entitled prisoners of war from the United Kingdom who are residing in Australia to receive treatment through the Australian repatriation system. As I understand the position, the cost of that is borne by the United Kingdom authorities. Bearing in mind the particular points Senator Harradine has just mentioned, I would need to obtain further advice as to the exact situation. I undertake to do that and bring down a reply for Senator Harradine.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Education. In introducing into the Senate the report of the Tertiary Education Commission on the last sitting day, he referred to the progress made with amalgamations of some colleges of advanced education and noted that colleges at Armidale, Newcastle, Milperra and Hawthorn were still requiring final amalgamation plans. In his statement the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Government's requirement for consolidation as a precondition for 1983 and 1984 funding has not altered and it is now urgent for decisions to be taken.

Can the Minister elaborate on the urgency with regard to the legislation that is to proceed during this parliamentary session, on the basis of the report and the Government's announcements and with regard to the courses being available to students in these colleges for the coming academic year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that a number of amalgamations are yet to be put into place among those which were indicated as being required by the Government in April 1981. That is some 18 months ago. The Government allowed 1981 and 1982 for the institutions involved to make appropriate arrangements. I am advised by the Victorian Government that agreement is likely between the Institute of Early Childhood Development and the State College of Victoria, Melbourne, for one amalgamation. I understand that some details are still to be worked out there. There are some points of disagreement which I hope will be overcome. Although there are still some points of disagreement there is likely to be some progress there. In relation to Armidale, I have been advised by the College of Advanced Education that it is willing, albeit reluctantly, to engage in amalgamation discussions. It is the University of New England which is refusing to progress the matter, the University, of course, considering itself free from any financial duress by the Government. In relation to the other two institutions, discussions are going on as regards the Milperra CAE and the Hawthorn State College as to appropriate arrangements which might be made or are possible. A number of proposals are being developed.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth laid down the end of 1982 as the time by which it required appropriate arrangements to be in place. In many cases these arrangements involve State legislation being passed. There are only two States-New South Wales and Victoria-in which amalgamations are yet to be put into place. In both of those States the parliamentary sittings may well be complete within the next 2 1/2 months. It is very important that those States have a capacity to introduce and to consider whatever legislation is necessary to give effect to the amalgamations which take place. The report of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission merely reiterated our concern and our determination on these matters that there should be appropriate arrangements. I hope to introduce the appropriate States grants legislation within the next week or two to provide funding. That legislation will contain some provisions to take account of those amalgamations which are in place already, those which are proposed and those which have not yet been proposed or suggested. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — With regard to the second part of the question, I am unaware of what was said at yesterday's Estimates Committee hearing by the Crown Solicitor or his representatives.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

I understand that consideration is being given by the Minister to providing further staff to enable the Department to look at those who are in this country as illegal immigrants and to take whatever steps are necessary in that connection. —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and refers to the remarks he made at Bendigo at the weekend which were referred to earlier by Senator Button. Why did the Minister feel it necessary to reassure those who deprive consolidated revenue of many hundreds of millions of dollars of funds through tax avoidance schemes that they would not be subject to criminal prosecution? What different principle applies which allows him at the same time to have his Department continuing a policy of vigorous criminal prosecution of those who have been involved in depriving the revenue of much smaller sums? Many of these people are Aboriginals, single parents and unemployed people. Some of them, according to reports, have poor literacy and education and therefore may be ignorant of the law. Why is it necessary for the Minister to make this distinction between these two groups of people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is, of course, no such distinction drawn. As I indicated in response to an earlier question, the legislation which we passed in 1980 was unprecedented in imposing criminal penalties against certain tax offences. I have a copy of that Act in front of me. I notice in section 9 the penalty of imprisonment for a period not exceeding five years or a fine not exceeding $50, 000 or both on conviction for an offence under this Act.

ANSWER.PARA: The particular remarks which were reported in the newspaper were part of a speech which covered a series of matters to a meeting of the Liberal Party. It dealt with the recent Budget. I mentioned the question of the proposed taxation legislation because, of course, that is a matter which has been very much in the public eye of late. I think my comment to that particular meeting was that I thought it would have been rather artificial and strange not to have at least devoted some remarks to it. I therefore gave a brief explanation of what was proposed. The reason for mentioning the question of criminal penalties was that it had come to my attention that there was some confusion in some sections of the public; people thought that what was proposed was the imposition of criminal penalties on vendor shareholders as against the recovery of taxes. In the course of my remarks I clarified that point.

As far as the vigorous program for prosecution of offenders under the social security legislation is concerned, I think that is an unpardonable bit of political hyperbole on the part of the Opposition spokesman for social security because I think he knows that that does not truly represent the activities and actions of my Department. We have a significant task in trying to ensure that the very large social security system is not abused by the minority of people who set out to abuse it. A week or so ago in this place I was asked a question, as I recall it, about an allegation of one case of abuse involving, according to the newspapers, $100,000 in wrongly claimed unemployment benefit. The case involved an individual who was alleged to have used a series of false birth certificates to claim, from a series of offices of my Department, social security benefits to which he was not entitled. That sort of fraud is no more pardonable and no more acceptable than frauds upon the revenue, and I believe that we have to try to take an even-handed approach in these matters. We should certainly be as concerned by one area of abuse as another.

Very often the substantial number of relatively small overpayments which are detected by my Department are caused by errors or omissions. Of course, the great bulk of them do not give rise to prosecution. Some of them give rise to recovery action; some do not. It is a feature of the work of the benefits control officers of my Department that a significant proportion of their work involves discovering underpayments to our clients and resultant increased payments to those people who are investigated. I cannot off the top of my head give the percentage figure, but I think that about 30 per cent of cases disclose underpayment rather than overpayment and consequently are for the benefit of those people about whom inquiry is made.

As I think I mentioned in the Senate last week, there are two separate aspects of the work of the Department of Social Security. One is to ensure that all those people who are entitled to benefits receive them, and we conscientiously seek to do that. The more difficult part of our task is to try to ensure that those people who try to obtain benefits to which they are not entitled do not receive them. Of course, the dilemma is that we try to operate systems which are accessible to people in the community, many of whom are not the most able to use bureaucratic procedures, to fill in forms and so on. There is a very fine balance to be made between prevention of fraud and ensuring that people have a system which is manageable.

I say again to the Senate that we try to maintain a fair and reasonable balance in these matters. If Senator Grimes can bring forward examples of what he regards as improper prosecutions or in any sense victimisation of the clients of my Department, of course we will seek to follow them up and to root them out. I reject the criticism which he tries to make in the comparison which he has drawn . I simply remind him of the report of last week; the very substantial fraud in that case is a useful reminder of the difficult balance that we have to maintain .

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his little lecture. I was trying to ascertain why the Minister took a different attitude in his speech in Bendigo from the approach of his Department. To clarify that, I ask: Is it not a fact that the Prime Minister, in his statement on Sunday 12 September, made it perfectly clear that he, and therefore I believe the Government, does not believe that anyone could have taken part in bottom-of- the-harbour schemes without knowing they were wrong? Therefore, these people knowingly deprived the revenue illegally of funds. Why is it necessary for the Minister to make this distinction between these people, who after all defrauded the revenue of much more than the people involved with the Department of Social Security? Why did he find it necessary to assure them that they would not be treated as criminals nor would they be subject to criminal charges when that does not apply to people who, according to many surveys, may have done similar things with the Department of Social Security out of ignorance or out of lack of understanding of the system?

—I suppose it is to the political advantage of the Opposition to attempt to sow confusion in these matters but I now have before me the newspaper report on which the question was based. I say first of all that it is quite clear-this perhaps relates more to Senator Button's question-that my remarks as reported related to prospective legislation and not to the legislation which was passed in 1980. It says: 'We are not going to legislate to say'. In other words, it is referring to the legislation which is ahead. In any event, the full remarks that I made certainly were relevant to that. There is probably a fairly clear understanding in this place that what has been addressed by the Treasurer in his recent remarks are the claims that are to be made on those who are described as vendor shareholders, persons who have sold to individuals who have subsequently behaved in the manner proscribed by the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980. A distinction is to be drawn between those who have actively stripped and rendered companies incapable of paying taxation and those who have sold shares to people who have then carried out those activities. The honourable senator, in asking his question, used the expression 'without knowing they were wrong'. I would say that we are in an area in which one is making judgments about right or wrong. There is no suggestion here of dealing in a field of straight illegality. Hence one is making judgments about right and wrong. In these circumstances the Government has indicated that it proposes to legislate to recover the taxation due, even though that is an unusual procedure.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations whether he is aware that private banks in Australia have made large profits, some $573m last year, due partially at least to the introduction of new technology? Is the Minister also aware that, by granting the request of bank employees for a nine-day working fortnight, the banks could create almost 7,000 new jobs for young Australians and in so doing distribute to their employees and the public generally some of the advantages of automation? Is the Minister aware that the cost of providing these new jobs, as projected by the banks themselves, is only about $70m, or only some 13 per cent of a single year's profits? Does the Minister agree that automation is basically beneficial to the community but that, if it is to gain acceptance, some sharing of the benefits thereof must go to the community and workers, otherwise a neo-Luddite community attitude is inevitable? I make the general comment that the move to the working of shorter hours for the same rate of pay is one that has not been generally welcomed by the Government, given Australia's current economic circumstances. Certainly in general the Government would take the view that to increase the unit cost of labour is not helpful to Australia, with its current international competitiveness and so on. I will refer the broader aspects of the question to Mr Macphee for his consideration. This claim was allegedly made in the latest issue of Choice, the magazine of the Australian Consumers Association. Will the Minister ensure that the Department of Health investigates the claims made by Choice and, if those claims and findings are correct, will he take the necessary steps to safeguard Australian consumers by setting the standards at the maximum level of safety?

—I believe that the standards referred to in the newspaper article to which Senator Lajovic referred were established by the Australian Standards Association. I can assure Senator Lajovic that I will have his question drawn to the attention of Mr Carlton to see whether this is a matter that the NHMRC should consider further. I am not certain that it has not already put the matter under study, but I will obtain that information for Senator Lajovic. There are several kinds of ultraviolet light, some of which are harmful in that they help cause skin cancer. Australia, unfortunately, leads the world in terms of the incidence of skin cancer.
—Check all those clinics that are growing up.

—The honourable senator asks that we look into this for health reasons. I accept Senator Sibraa's interjection. I am aware that the honourable senator has had a long-standing interest in this matter and I acknowledge that commercial solaria which use ultraviolet light should be among the first to implement the standard established by the Australian Standards Association, especially in view of the information from Choice that a large number of ultravoilet apparatuses are unsafe in terms of the standard laid down.

Is the Minister aware that the men have now been on strike for the last five weeks and that some families are experiencing great difficulty? Is he also aware that his office is not directing the attention of those people to the fact that special grants can be made available to them if in fact hardship is being experienced? What action will the Minister take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the matter raised by the honourable senator. I hasten to say that no one else has drawn it to my attention. I am quite puzzled by the point she has made, as this Senate has rejected legislation which I introduced and which would have rendered ineligible for unemployment benefit the wives of strikers. Honourable senators will recall the Government's view that that is not an appropriate use of unemployment benefit. When will more staff be appointed to the Hobart tax office? How many will there be? Will the extra numbers all be allocated to the task of catching up with the tax evasion backlog? Will the Government acknowledge that the fact of these proposed appointments is an admission that its too restrictive staff ceilings have exacerbated the Taxation Office's difficulties in dealing with tax evasion? QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. With regard to the current oil industry dispute, is the present situation a case of disadvantaged and deprived workers operating in circumstances in which claims for wages and conditions need public sympathy and support, or is it, as reported, that a return to work is impossible because large numbers of the strikers are absent on the Gold Coast spending their already enormous and outrageous wages while holding the Australian public to ransom?

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the present rate of average pay for these workers? How does it compare with the wage of the average Australian blue-collar worker?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —From some of the interjections from honourable senators opposite it sounds as though some of them regard that as an inflammatory question. But I suggest to those who are agitated by it that the people of New South Wales probably find the behaviour of the Kurnell people even more inflammatory and are very keen to see the matter brought to an end.
—Hear, hear!

—I am pleased to hear the Leader of the Opposition saying 'hear, hear', and indeed I can be positive in responding to the question and say that it is a matter of satisfaction to the Government that the New South Wales Government, on this occasion, seems more anxious to take firm action in this dispute. I think that that is a response to the very deep public concern that exists about what has been far too frequently a sore on the body of industrial relations in New South Wales, and something which has been very deeply felt by many of the citizens of New South Wales because of the great inconvenience to which they have been subjected. The Federal Government joins the New South Wales Government in saying that all bans should be lifted and that the union should allow both State and Federal tribunals to proceed with the matters before them. As far as the particular workers are concerned, it is, of course, a feature of this dispute-I have noticed some public comment on it-that we are not dealing with workers who would be regarded as low-paid. The figures I have show that an operator on appointment receives a base rate of $323.40 a week. Whilst specific figures are not available, it is estimated that if such an operator adhered to the normal shift roster premiums and allowances would increase the base rate to an estimated average of $450 a week. An operator with five years service would receive an estimated average wage of $475 for working the normal shift cycle.

ANSWER.PARA: I suppose it is unfortunately true that once a person has been receiving that salary-which is certainly well above average weekly earnings and would be regarded by most Australians as very good remuneration-for a while it does not seem so much. I can understand that those workers would, in common with almost every other section of the Australian community, feel that they are underpaid and deserving of greater remuneration. That really highlights the importance of the people concerned seeing their position in light of the position of many of their fellow Australians, who are not nearly as well off, and being prepared to moderate their claims accordingly. I think all honourable senators would agree that the disputes which have afflicted this part of New South Wales industry are really something of a disgrace. We would all want the people concerned to return to work and use arbitration, and not the strike weapon-at great inconvenience to their fellow citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: — Senator Keeffe asked again a question which he had referred to me in August with regard to the domestic surplus on the last day of June 1982. I have the response from the Treasury which shows that Senator Keeffe is incorrect in suggesting that there was a political manipulation of the domestic surplus on the last day of the last financial year . The event to which he may be referring is the coincidence of the last day in the financial year 1981-82 with the normal schedule of payment of salaries of Commonwealth Public Service employees and pensions. The due date for these payments was Thursday, 1 July 1982, and an amount estimated at $430m was withdrawn on 30 June according to normal payment practices. About $180m of this $430m was credited automatically to the bank accounts of the recipients on 30 June. The remaining sum was held for distribution as cash or cheques on 1 July. Some cheques for employees in remote areas were mailed as early as the previous Friday, 25 June. The funds were not invested between their withdrawal and their use on 1 July 1982. In accordance with normal practice, these payments were all recorded in the Government's accounts on 30 June 1982 and were included in the financial year 1981-82. Therefore, there was no manipulation, political or otherwise, of the domestic surplus. The reason for drawing attention to these transactions in the Budget Papers was their delayed impact on measured money supply M3. This is explained in an attachment which the Treasury has sent to me . I seek leave to have that attachment incorporated in Hansard for Senator Keeffe's information.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows--
PAYDAY EFFECT

Commonwealth Budget outlays in 1981-82 included a Public Service and Social Security benefit payment on Wednesday, 30 June 1982, estimated at $430 million. The due date for this payment was Thursday, 1 July-the first day of the 1982-83 financial year. However, many payees have their payments automatically transferred to a bank account and these transactions-estimated at $180 million in total-took place on Wednesday, 30 June.

2. That part of the $430 million not automatically transferred to bank accounts-about $250 million-had no effect on measured money supply M3 in 1981- 82; the full impact occurred in July 1982. The other $180 million was recorded in bank deposits in 1981-82. But the full effect of this increase did not feed through into measured M3, which includes the increase in trading bank deposits on an average-of-Wednesdays rather than an end-of-month basis.

3. As a result, the payday on 30 June is estimated to have increased M3 by about $70 million in 1981-82, or by about 0.1 per cent of the June 1981 stock of M3; and by about $360 million in 1982-83, or by about 0.6 per cent of the stock of M3 in June 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MESSNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to enable appointments to be made of Special Prosecutors with clear authority and independence to institute in exceptional cases and carry on necessary prosecutions. These cases will be of such a special character that the community should not be left in the slightest doubt that prosecutions will be handled with the highest professional competence with complete independence from any extraneous consideration.

The first appointment of a Special Prosecutor will be of a person to assume overall responsibility for the handling of the prosecutions for the alleged taxation frauds referred to as bottom of the harbour schemes and for co- ordinating the recovery by civil remedies under existing law of the amounts thereby lost to the Commonwealth. This legislation is therefore a clear indication of the Government's intention to proceed with the utmost vigour in these cases regardless of all considerations other than the proper enforcement of the law and the protection of the revenue.

The principal task of a Special Prosecutor will be in relation to breaches of laws of the Commonwealth or a Territory but he will be able to conduct prosecutions for offences against the laws of a State where he receives an appropriate appointment by or under the law of the relevant State.

The Government is determined that the Special Prosecutor is backed and supported by all necessary staff including lawyers, accountants and investigating staff and special provision is made in clauses 17, 18 and 19 to ensure this result. The accountability of a Special Prosecutor is ensured by the requirement for annual reports of his operations. His independence is assured by the provisions of clause 7 limiting any direction or guidelines to directions or guidelines of a general character not relating to a particular case.

The speech read as follows-

This Bill continues the practice of introducing an omnibus Miscellaneous Amendments Bill during each period of sittings of the Parliament as an expeditious way of making amendments of a non-controversial character to a large number of Acts. Some of the amendments made by the Bill correct printing or drafting errors. Others make drafting or other technical amendments. Those provisions do not call for particular comment. Other provisions go into matters of substance in varying degrees. I propose to explain in some detail the nature and effect of those provisions. In addition, a detailed explanatory memorandum covering all the clauses of the Bill has been circulated.
Acts Interpretation Act 1901

Part VI of the Bill inserts in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 a definition of 'The Department'. It is hoped that this general definition will overcome to a large extent the need to separately define the word in particular legislation. Having regard to this amendment, the opportunity has been taken, in regard to the formal machinery of government amendments contained in Schedule 12 to the Bill, to rely as much as possible on that general definition.
Particular amendments made by various Parts of the Bill remove express references in Acts to particular Departments or to particular Permanent Heads of Departments.

Honourable Senators will recall the commitment I made to the Parliament in a statement concerning Parliamentary disallowance of delegated legislation on 26 May 1981 in relation to certain Reports of the Senate Standing Committee on Reglations and Ordinances. I then said that a careful study would be made of existing disallowance provisions with a view to also bringing those into line with the Government's policy that future disallowance provisions should, unless there is good reason to the contrary, incorporate the substance of the principles contained in sections 48, 49 and 50 of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

That study is now well underway and the amendments to the undermentioned Act brings those Acts into conformity with those sections of the Acts Interpretation Act to the extent practicable in the particular case:
Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders (Queensland Reserves and Communities Self-Management) Act 1978;
Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976;
Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976;
Customs Tariff 1966;
Dairy Industry Stabilization Act 1977;
Defence Act 1903;
Defence Amendment Act 1979;
Explosives Act 1961;
Representation Act 1905;
Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910; and
State Grants (Petroleum Products) Act 1965.
Amendments to other legislation if any, which should also be subject to the provisions contained in sections 48, 49 and 50 will be brought forward as identified.
Audit Act 1901

Section 62B of the Audit Act 1901 restricts the investment of moneys standing to the credit of the Trust Fund maintained under Part IX of the Act to Commonwealth and State securities, deposits in a bank and in the purchase of coinage. Part VII of the Bill amends section 62B of the Audit Act so as to provide wider avenues of investment of such moneys. The amendments will permit investment in securities issued by government authorities, on loans to authorised dealers in the official money market, in certificates of deposit and in clean bills of exchange. Also the Minister for Finance will be empowered to approve other suitable forms of investment.
Australian Federal Police Act 1979
Part XI of the Bill makes a number of amendments to improve the operation of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979.

Section 26A of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979 provides that former Narcotics Enforcement Branch staff may, if qualified and suitable, be appointed to the Australian Federal Police. Arising from recent legal advice the Government has become aware that persons so appointed might not, by reason of the legal preference contained in section 73 of the Act, have equal rights to promotion and transfer within the Australian Federal Police as former officers of the former Commonwealth Police Force and the Police Force of the Australian Capital Territory. The Bill makes the necessary amendments to the Australian Federal Police Act to ensure that equality.
Banking Act 1959

Part XII of the Bill adds a new Part IIA to the Banking Act 1959 to facilitate the operation of State and Northern Territory legislation relating to the merging of the banking businesses, respectively, of the Bank of New South Wales and the Commercial Bank of Australia Limited, and of The National Bank of Australasia Limited and The Commercial Banking Company of Sydney Limited.

Legislation now passed (or in course of passage) in each of the States and the Northern Territory will assist the merging banks and their many customers by removing the administrative burden that would otherwise be involved in completing the merger of the banks' businesses in those jurisdictions. Within the Australian Capital Territory Ordinances will shortly be made to facilitate the merger of the banks' businesses in the Territory.

The amendments made to the Banking Act by Part XII of the Bill will remove a range of uncertainties arising from potential inconsistences between various areas of Commonwealth legislation and the abovementioned State and Territory legislation. The amendments made by the Bill to the Banking Act will avoid the possibility that, by reason of any such inconsistency, some portion of the relevant State or Northern Territory legislation might be held to be invalid. In addition, the amendments to the Banking Act provide for the States and Northern Territory legislation to bind the Crown in the right of the Commonwealth, of the Northern Territory and of Norfolk Island.

Provision is also made by the Bill for the amendments I have outlined to be applied, at the discretion of the Treasurer in the event of any future bank merger being implemented by the same method as has been adopted for these mergers. No such merger is, of course, contemplated at this time, and I remind honourable senators that in granting his consent under section 63 of the Banking Act to the present mergers the Treasurer pointed out that it should not be assumed that consent would necessarily be forthcoming in respect of any future merger proposals. Nevertheless, in the event at some future time of a merger being duly considered and accepted, this provision would obviate the need for further Commonwealth legislative action to ensure that no constitutional difficulties arises from the enactment of State and Territory facilitating legislation.

I should point out that the amendments of the Banking Act made by the Bill will not have the effect of altering the substantive rights and obligations which presently exist between the continuing banks and their customers. It simply ensures that the business of the merged banks is able to be transferred to the continuing banks with minimum disruption to the service provided by the banks.
Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918

The amendment made by Part XVI of the Bill allows licenced premises to be used as polling booths provided the Chief Australian Electoral Officer is satisfied that no intoxicating liquor is available for sale on those premises whilst they are being so used. Typical examples of such premises would be licenced Town Halls in the larger towns and the cities.
Companies Act 1981
The Bill provides for two categories of amendment of the Companies Act 1981. The amendments have been approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities.

The first category, which involves amendments to sections 509 and 517 of the Principal Act, is designed to ensure that there is greater consistency in the obligations imposed on different types of corporations as to the amount of information which they must disclose on documents such as cheques. This consistency is to be achieved by a reduction in the amount of information required.

Pursuant to the amendments made by the Bill, it will no longer be necessary for any corporation to indicate on bills of exchange, promissory notes, cheques or other negotiable instruments any details as to the State or Territory in which it is incorporated, registered as a foreign company, or formed, as the case may be. It is mentioned that under the Companies Act 1981 as it presently operates, an officer of such a corporation who signs such a document in the A.C.T. could be liable to the holder of the document if he does not indicate the requisite details.

The amendments will also relieve any corporation, which has limited liability but does not have the words 'Limited' in its name, of the need to indicate in those same documents that it has limited liability.

Both types of information covered by the abovementioned amendments will still be required in any business letter, statement of account, invoice, order for goods, order for services, receipt, official notice or publication of a company.

The second category of amendment to the Principal Act involves amendments to sections 5 and 581. Those amendments are designed to preserve the operation of the provisions of three A.C.T. Ordinances which are dependant on the relevant companies legislation in force in the A.C.T. at any particular time.
Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1972

The amendment made by Part XXI of the Bill allows a Deputy President whose present appointment to office ran until he attains the age of seventy years to be appointed as President of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission without any diminution of the right to serve until he attains the age of seventy years. The amendment ensures that if such a person is appointed as President he is not required to retire at the age of sixty-five years which would otherwise be the case with all new appointments to presidential office in the Commission.
Defence Service Homes Act 1918

At present, assistance under the Defence Service Homes Act 1918 cannot be given to an eligible person if he or his spouse owns another home. One effect of this provision is to exclude from assistance a person who does not own a home and who is permanently separated, but not divorced, from his spouse if that spouse owns a home. The proposed amendments will enable an advance to be made in such circumstances notwithstanding the separated spouse's ownership of a home.
Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975

Part XXXVI of the Bill amends sub-section 66 (5) of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975 to overcome a practical problem which has become evident in the light of experience with the preparation of zoning plans for newly declared areas of the Marine Park.

Sub-section 66 (5) of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act provides that regulations shall not apply to an area within the Marine Park in respect of which no zoning plan is in force if more than 12 months has elapsed since that area became part of the Marine Park. Experience has shown that, because of the timing requirements in the Principal Act relating to the preparation of zoning plans, the period of 12 months has proved to be insufficient. The amendment to sub-section 66 (5) made by the Bill will allow regulations to apply to such areas for a period of up to 2 years from the date an area becomes part of the Marine Park. The amendment will avoid interim regulations lapsing before a zoning plan comes into effect.
Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976

The amendments made by Part XLIV of the Bill seek to overcome certain technical deficiencies in the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976. They will ensure that the Government's longstanding policy intentions, in respect of the provision of encouragement by way of commencement grant to companies to commence systematic research and development activities, are given full effect.

The Act was intended to provide that entitlements of any company to commencement grants be restricted to five consecutive years, with this entitlement reduced by one year for each grant received under the preceding grants scheme. This policy was announced when the Act was first introduced in the Parliament in 1976. It has been very well publicised since.

However, amendments made to the Act in 1981 did not adequately secure this policy of limited entitlement. The proposed amendments to sections 25 and 26A will overcome these deficiencies. The much simplified section 25 will establish the term of available assistance. Amended section 26A will prevent circumvention of the intent of section 25 by ensuring that the device of corporate restructuring is not available to beneficiaries as a means of securing additional assistance under the commencement grant provisions or the preceding grants scheme.

The amendments made by Part XLIV of the Bill also relate to the cut-off date for lodging of applications for commencement grants. Previously similar provision had been made for the purpose by regulation but recent legal advice has expressed doubt about the validity of that regulation. The provision now to be made in the Act will provide for a cut-off date of 30 September next after the end of the grant year. Also there will no longer be a discretion to extend that date. The amendments will provide an automatic extension for lodging an application to 30 November next in each grant year provided the company concerned had notified, before 30 September, that it will be unable to meet that cut-off date. Where an application covered by that automatic extension to 30 November is received, the amendments made by the Bill will provide for deferral of payment of a commencement grant to the next financial year.
Navigation Act 1912

The main feature of the amendments made by Part XLVIII of the Bill to the Navigation Act 1912 is to provide that regulations made pursuant to various sections of the Act may empower the Minister to make orders in respect of matters able to be prescribed by the regulations made under those sections.

The Bill also inserts a new section 295B in the Navigation Act to give effect to an agreement between the Commonwealth Government and the Government of Victoria to exempt historic shipwrecks and relics within the waters of that State from the provisions of the Act governing the salvage and disposal of wrecks. The amendments made by clauses 176 and 177 gives to historic shipwrecks and historic relics within the meaning of a law of a State or of the Northern Territory relating to such shipwrecks or relics the same exemption as have Commonwealth historic wrecks from certain provisions of the Act.

Two further amendments made by the Bill will provide procedural improvements in the administration of the Act. A ship survey authority will be able to be approved by Ministerial instrument rather than by the regulations. Furthermore, dangerous goods now to be identified for the purpose of the carriage provisions of the Act, by express reference to the International Maritime Dangerous Goods Code, which is an extensive and frequently amended publication of the International Maritime Organization.
Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946

Under the original provisions of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967, laws in force in the relevant States and Territories, including Commonwealth Acts, are applied to activities connected with petroleum exploration and exploitation activities in the offshore 'adjacent area' of the State or Territory in question as defined in the Schedules to that Act.

With the entry into force of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act 1980 , however, such Commonwealth Acts will cease to apply automatically in adjacent areas. The scope of the application of Commonwealth Act will then be a matter to be provided for specifically in the particular Act.

At present, the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia) operates services to oil exploration and drilling platforms or structures on the continental shelf. Without the amendments made by Part LII of the Bill, to the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946, the validity of the services provided by the Overseas Telecommunications Commission (Australia) in adjacent area would be in doubt when the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act 1980 comes into force.
These amendments therefore apply the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946 in the offshore ''adjacent area'' when the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act comes into force.

Similar amendments are also required to the Postal Services Act 1975 in respect of services provided by the Australian Postal Commission and to the Telecommunications Act 1975, in respect of services provided by the Australian Telecommunications Commission. The necessary amendments are made by Parts LVII and LXXIII respectively of the Bill.
Parliament House Construction Authority Act 1979
The main purposes of the amendments made by Part LIII of the Bill to the Parliament House Construction Authority Act 1979 are to:
enable the Parliament House Construction Authority to delegate its powers, except for the power of delegation, to the Chief Executive or another officer of the Authority;
change the title of the Executive Officer of the Authority to that of Chief Executive; and

enable a resolution to be deemed to have been duly passed if a majority of the members sign a document or documents stating that they are in favour of the resolution of the Authority as set out in the document or documents.
Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967

In Part LIV of the Bill the boundaries of the Queensland adjacent area under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967 are amended to take into account the Australia/France Maritime Boundary Agreement signed on 4 January 1982. The Agreement requires the removal of a small portion of the Queensland adjacent area and allows the extension of the area over part of Australia's continental shelf not previously covered by the offshore petroleum legislation.
Public Accounts Committee Act 1951

The Public Accounts Committee Act 1951 provides for the formation of Sectional Committees of three or more members and that the provisions applying in relation to the Committee, with some exceptions, apply to the Sectional Committees. Since the 1979 amendments to the Act difficulties have arisen in application of the quorum provision to those Sectional Committees which have only a small number of members. The amendments made by the Bill to Section 9 of the Act specify the quorum of a Sectional Committee depending on the number of members of the Committee.
Science and Industry Research Act 1949

Part LXVI of the Bill amends the provision made by the Science and Industry Research Act 1949 which established the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Organisation State Committees in each of the six States. In 1981, following representations from the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, the Government established a CSIRO Committee in the Northern Territory administratively. The amendment made by Part LXVI now puts the Northern Territory Committee on a statutory basis.
Primary Industry Legislation

Finally, a number of amendments of a minor nature are made by the Bill to certain primary industry legislation, designed to facilitate the operation of various statutory bodies and to make other improvements related to the administration of that legislation. These provisions are explained in the Explanatory memorandum that has been circulated. The Parts in question are Parts VIII, X, XV, XXV, XXVI, XXXI, XXXII, XLII, XVIII, XLV, XLVI, LV, LVI, LVIII and LIX.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
