This Bill is intended to ensure that the Australian Omega navigation facility can be operated free from unnecessary interruption.

The Australian Omega station completes a world-wide network of eight stations. The other seven stations are operated by Argentina, Japan, Liberia, Norway, France (at La Reunion), and the United States of America (at Hawaii and North Dakota). The Omega system is a long-range radio navigation system for use by aircraft, ships and land vehicles to determine their position in virtually any part of the world and in any weather. Each station transmits omnidirectional signals in the very low frequency radio band. In the usual mode of operation, a receiver needs to detect signals from at least three Omega stations to determine a position-fix. Omega receivers of varying complexity are available from commercial sources throughout the world.

The Governments of Australia and the United States of America entered into an exchange of notes in 1977, agreeing to the establishment and operation of the Australian station. The agreement has been previously tabled and is reproduced in the Schedule to the Bill.

The agreement provides that Australia is to be solely responsible for operating , managing, staffing and maintaining the facility and that each Government is required to ensure the continuous operation of its respective facilities.

The Australian facility comprises a transmitter and associated equipment located on Commonwealth land near Darriman in Victoria, and monitoring equipment located on Commonwealth land near Carrajung, also in Victoria. The facility commenced transmitting on a fully operational basis on 16 August and is to be officially opened in October, this year.

Being an integral part of the world-wide Omega system, it is essential that the Government take all necessary steps to ensure the uninterrupted operation of the Australian facility. The Government believes this Bill to be an appropriate measure to deal with any threat of irresponsible action to interfere with transmissions by the Australian facility.

Under the Bill, where circumstances necessitate, persons who ordinarily supply goods or services required for use in connection with the Omega facility may be directed by the Minister to supply such goods or services. Obstruction of the supply of goods or services, and refusal to carry out a direction of the Minister are defined in the Bill as offences. The Bill also ensures access to the facility by persons whose access is sufficiently important to warrant protection.

One of the objects of the Bill is to secure State co-operation in the continued operation and maintenance of the Omega facility. State laws consistent with that object are preserved. However, State laws that conflict with the purposes of the Bill are set aside.

The Bill operates concurrently with other laws, particularly those relating to protection of property and the safety of navigation aids. In addition it contains a provision to ensure that the prosecution of offences in relation to Omega can be undertaken by the Commonwealth without having to rely on State action.
If a person suffers loss or damage or property is acquired from him as a result of the operation of the Bill, he is entitled to compensation from the Commonwealth on just terms.

In conclusion, the Government's objective is to provide effective navigational aids for the safety of ships and aircraft operating in and around Australia, particularly those engaged in our coastal and overseas trades. The establishment of the Omega facility is a significant step towards the achievement of that objective, and the purpose of the Bill is to ensure that the operation of the facility is not disrupted.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Amendment Bill is an important Bill. Its prime objective is to provide a long overdue increase in penalties for Customs offences. The Opposition does not oppose it. We take the view, as we have always done, that Customs offences must be treated seriously, as of course Mr MacKellar and Mr Moore found out even before this increase in penalties. For all the familiar reasons, especially deterrents and protection of revenue, we believe that penalties must bear a reasonable relationship to the nature of the offence.

SPEECH.PARA: Before dealing with the Bill, it is appropriate to advert to a matter which is much more immediately relevant to the effectiveness of Customs and excise legislation than the level of penalties, that is, the effectiveness and efficiency of Customs administration. In this respect one must now refer to the statement last Sunday, 12 September, of the Acting Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Fife. He indicated that the Government was about to set in train a major restructing of the Bureau of Customs in each State and the renaming of the Bureau as the Australian Customs Service. It appears that what is being contemplated is, in the language of Mr Fife, the most comprehensive exercise undertaken in Customs since federation. It is also said by Mr Fife that it represents the product of consultations over a considerable period, particularly the last 18 months.

Four areas of change are set out-firstly, a strengthened organisation and strengthened operational procedures to upgrade further Customs controls; secondly, the formation of a single Customs officer career stream with the amalgamation of the two existing divisional groups; thirdly, extensive and comprehensive retraining programs for existing staff; and, finally, a completely revised recruitment and a 12 months full time training program for future Customs officers. Unfortunately, the general description of what is intended is not accompanied by any documentation or other descriptive material which would enable one to assess with any degree of confidence just what in fact is being proposed. There is an extraordinary degree of generality about the language of Mr Fife's one and a half page release not only in respect of the four general areas covered, which I have just recounted, but also in the other descriptions. For example, Mr Fife said:

The application of controls to implement Government policies for community and industry protection and revenue collection will be supported by the introduction of improved risk assessment techniques, upgraded training programs and a more dynamic approach to the deployment of staff in all areas of Customs activities.

Each one of those descriptions could mean absolutely anything and, until we get some supplementary further and better particulars, it is difficult to comment or respond sensibly on what is proposed. Similarly, Mr Fife makes this further statement:
The effectiveness of the existing staff would be maximised with the introduction of widened and more responsible duties for officers and more flexible working arrangements.

Again one is left with a sense of mystery about what in fact is being proposed. We need more detail and I ask the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) in his response to tell the Senate whether and when a full report will be made available with details as to the general matters to which I have already referred and also the 'complete review of more than 3,800 positions', together with the timetable for the proposed implementation procedures to take effect. It is all very well for the Minister to be 'confident that the new Australian Customs Service will result in improved standards of service in the vital spheres of community and industry protection'. If he wants us to believe him, he will have to tell us a bit more than what is contained in this rather derisory Press statement.

I say all this on behalf of the Opposition because of our well known concern, articulated on numerous occasions particularly in the aftermath of the MacKellar -Moore affair, that there is a degree of unhappiness in the way the present service operates. There have been numerous allegations of inefficiency and worse from a variety of sources in regard to the way in which the Bureau operates. I understand that there is still in train, although it is hardly referred to in Mr Fife's statement, a detailed review by Mr Frank Mahony of the operation of the present Bureau of Customs in New South Wales. The likely outcome of that review is not something which is referred to, let alone apparently accommodated, in the present proposal. On several occasions following the MacKellar-Moore affair we have called for a full judiciary inquiry and we will go on indicating our lack of happiness with the way the Bureau and the Customs service has operated until we get, as I said before, some further and better particulars. That is not to say that we want to be taken as being in any way critical of the matters set out in this release because it may well be, particularly if the language is matched by the reality, that we do have here the prospect of some very significant changes. But there are problems and they will not simply go away by the use of fine words and one and a half page Press releases. We need some more details.

One further point that ought to be made in this respect to press home the nature of our concern is the circumstance reported in the Press last week that Mr Tony Mayhew, the Customs officer at the centre of the MacKellar-Moore colour television affair, is to retire early because of ill health. Mr Mayhew was the officer who intervened at Sydney Airport in October 1981 when he saw the Minister in question carrying the unit and who set in train the subsequent course of events. He was the officer subsequently accused within the Bureau of a variety of irrational, emotional and agitated behaviour. It has been claimed on Mr Mayhew's behalf by Mr Bennett, the President of the New South Wales branch of the Customs Officers Association of Australia, that Mr Mayhew simply would not have retired early-or at least the numbers of years early that he is retiring- except for the pressure he came under during and after the colour television affair. I am well aware that this is the sort of matter presumably being dealt with by the Mahoney review but it does indicate that there are attentions, doubts and concerns about the operation of the present Bureau in a variety of jurisdictions. We remain unconvinced that really serious endeavours are being made to resolve that situation. We will be sceptical until we see the words matched by action.

I turn to the Bill before the Senate. It is essentially a machinery measure which amends the Customs Act primarily by substantially raising the level of penalties for breaches of the Act, excluding narcotics related offences which were the subject of legislation in 1979 following the report of the Williams Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs. The structure and the detail of the offences in the Customs legislation and the penalty and prosecution provisions of the existing Act have undergone only very limited change since 1901. There is no question but that very substantial review and revision on all fronts was called for.

The inadequacy of current penalties is highlighted by a number of considerations. For example, penalties for narcotics offences are now dramatically higher than those for other prohibited imports and exports. That may be appropriate in some circumstances but not necessarily in all. Again, most non-narcotic offence penalties have not been varied since 1967. A typical maximum fine is only $1,000. For some offences it is only $50. Again, the horse and kangaroo meat scandal recently revealed that penalties were quite inadequate in relation to the multi-million dollar benefits that evasion of Customs duty can bring when well organised frauds are in issue. There are other examples of that kind which have been canvassed in the other place, and I do not stop to go over them in too much laborious detail now.

Proposed penalties include the following: Where revenue is evaded, the penalty is to be at least twice and up to five times the amount evaded. Where prohibited exports or imports are involved, the maximum penalty will be three times their value. Where the value cannot be ascertained, there is a maximum fine now set at $50,000. There is another category of offences which 'strike at the basis of Customs control'-for example, interfering with a container before clearance by Customs, which will now carry a penalty again of $50,000 with lesser offences carrying penalties of between $1,000 and $10,000. These penalties do not seem to the Opposition to be unreasonable and they appear to it in all the circumstances to be appropriate to the offences concerned.

We notice that gaol terms are not specified, unlike in the narcotics context, which involves not only fines but also imprisonment. I suppose that there is a question as to whether that residual penalty, gaol, might not be appropriate in certain circumstances, particularly where very large sums of money or very deliberate frauds, such as the horse meat racket, are involved. We note further that, consequent upon the increased penalties, other amendments increase the jurisdictional level of lower and intermediate courts. Previously, because most fines were under $1,000, matters were dealt with by courts of summary jurisdiction and intermediate courts. The amendments now allow courts of summary jurisdiction to deal with matters up to the level of $5,000 and courts of intermediate jurisdiction to deal with matters up to the level of $20,000. There are other matters of that kind-for example, provision is being made to enable offences involving duty evasion of less than $500 to be dealt with administratively, as are presently small offences committed by arriving international travellers and crew. All those matters we regard as appropriate.

Other changes in the Bill-which I retail again more or less to indicate simply that we have read it, because we do not oppose them-include a new Part VA, which provides for the licensing of depots which hold goods prior to examination by Customs, which provisions are virtually identical to existing provisions relating to licensing warehouses. Again, there is a whole miscellany of amendments which update procedures and a number of other matters. These are the kind of amendments that are made virtually every year as circumstances and practices change, following what has necessarily been a process of continuous review of the legislation. Again, we have no unfavourable comments to make in that general area.

However, a number of submissions have been received by all members of parliament, I guess-certainly by those of us with the responsibility of carriage of these matters-addressing themselves to particular matters which have given cause for concern. I refer in particular to the extensive submissions that we have received from the Australian Federation of Air Freight Forwarders, from the Australian Chamber of Shipping and from the Distilled Spirits Industry Council of Australia, all of which bodies have a very direct and immediate commercial interest in the viability of this legislation.

Perhaps the area that has provoked most widespread concern goes to questions of the right of appeal from or review of various administrative decisions. It has been proposed, for example, that there be review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of administrative decisions made pursuant to those sections of the Customs Act which are either amended or initiated by clauses 7, 10, 12, 14 and 30 of this Bill. As to these matters, we know that the Government has received these submissions, but there simply was not any acknowledgment of that fact in the House of Representatives debate. Mr John Brown, our spokesman, specifically mentioned the submissions and gave them to the Minister acting in this area, Mr Hodgman, who said that he would follow up the question and get back to our spokesman, which I understand he has never done. So, as far as we know and as far as, I understand, the lobbyists know, there simply has not been a satisfactory response to the matters which I mention.

What I take this opportunity to do now is simply again to ask the Minister to assure the Senate in his response that these matters were examined by the Government and, more importantly, that they will be referred specifically to the Administrative Review Council, which is reviewing, as part of a large task, the adequacy of review and appeal mechanisms in the Customs area. We do not on this occasion express necessarily any decided view as to the appropriateness of appeal or review provisions being upgraded in the way that has been requested. We are simply concerned and keen to establish that the Government understands the nature of the arguments that are being put by the bodies most affected by this issue and has taken them on board and, to the extent that it has not been able to on this occasion, will refer them to the Administrative Review Council.

As to rights of appeal, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has been concerned with the lack of rights of appeal apparent in clauses 7, 12, 14 and 32 of this Bill and as to the non-appealable discretions vested in the Minister with respect to fees in clauses 18 and 24. Senator Tate will, I understand, have a little more to say about the recommendations of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in this and, perhaps, other areas. I simply make the point that it seems that the Government's view is that these matters are inappropriate for review. I believe, with the other members of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee , and indeed to the extent that these points are also made by the lobbyists to which I have referred, that it is appropriate that reconsideration be given by the Government to the provision of a right of review or appeal in this area. Again, I ask that we be assured that the Administrative Review Council has been given the very specific job of looking at these matters and advising the Government on them.

Another matter which has been of concern to those who have made more extensive submissions in this area is clause 24 of the Bill, which creates a new section- section 106 (2) (d). What is in issue here is misleading statements by persons and the relevance of those to the question whether the persons are fit and proper to hold a licence. The suggestion being made is that misleading statements should have implications for the granting of a licence only in the event that the statement was knowingly made. This is a matter about which reasonable men, not to mention reasonable women, can differ, as to the appropriateness of implying or requiring some mens rea test, perhaps. Again, my inclination and that of the Opposition is to take the view that this is a reasonable request. It may be that there are other policy considerations which need to be taken into account. I simply ask on this matter not that the Government reconsider the legislation here and now, but that next time the Bill is being amended-it is a fairly constant process with customs and excise legislation-further consideration be given to that question.

There is one remaining matter that gets attention from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in its report on this Bill and that is clause 17, which amends existing section 82 (1). At present section 82 (1) (c) obliges warehouse licence holders to give the Comptroller of Customs written particulars of the bankruptcy or certain convictions of any 'person who participates in the management or control of the warehouse' within 30 days of that happening. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has suggested that this obligation should fall only where a licence holder again knows or ought reasonably to have known about the convictions in question. This is a question which we do not propose to push to the stage of a Committee stage amendment but it is an appropriate matter which we draw to the attention of the Government for consideration the next time this legislation is reviewed.

I have referred to a variety of matters, some of which might be thought more appropriate for the Committee stage. I simply wish to express in a compendious way, and not to trouble the Senate at the Committee stage with any further articulation of these matters, what some of the areas of concern in fact are. I ask the Government in its response to indicate that all these points have been taken on board and that they will be given its usual sensitive, sympathetic and intelligent consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Customs and Excise Amendment Bill 1982 has had a somewhat tortuous passage through the Parliament. It was first introduced on 24 March of this year by Mr John Moore, the then Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. The legislation has survived two changes of Ministers and a change of department. It now comes for consideration by the Senate. The main purpose of the Bill, as was outlined quite fully by Senator Evans, is to increase the penalties for Customs offences. On this aspect of the Bill we are in complete agreement. The whole Customs administration is long overdue for a thorough review. This Bill goes a long way to tightening up many of the procedures and giving customs procedures that have grown up over the years the benefit of legislation to cover these practices.

SPEECH.PARA: The existing penalties, of course, were quite obviously inadequate. We believe that this Bill is important in that the penalties are substantially increased. We congratulate the Government on bringing forward this Bill and we support the main thrust of what it seeks to achieve. We also congratulate the Government on its announcement that the whole former Bureau of Customs is to be streamlined and made more efficient. We think this is very much to the good in an area that obviously needs very detailed attention. It needs detailed attention because, of course, we in this country are being subjected to organised crime which is directing its attention to the importation of illegal commodities and drugs. We must have an efficient Australian Customs Service.

We received, as did the Australian Labor Party, submissions from various industry groups. These submissions were quite detailed and cogently argued. As we always do when we receive submissions from industry and concerned parties, we considered them very carefully. In fact, we even went to the point of having amendments drafted to cover some of the more important submissions from various industry groups. Parker and Lord, for instance, Customs attorneys, had no fewer than eight suggestions for amendments to this legislation. I want to make it clear that we considered their amendments carefully and, as I have said, even went to the point of drafting amendments. But for a variety of reasons, on which I intend to touch only briefly, we do not propose to move any of these amendments at this stage. Nevertheless, it is worthy of note that the Government seems to have dismissed the industries' submissions in a very high-handed way. In fact, in the other place it went so far as to deny knowledge of some of the submissions which we find almost incredible. Leaving that aside I turn to the point Senator Tate raised. Many of these submissions would present very considerable difficulties in the drafting of legislation. Senator Evans touched on some of those difficulties so I will not go over that ground again. But to suggest in submissions a requirement that the legislation take account of whether somebody knowingly gives evidence is, I think, being a little optimistic .

We felt that most of the submissions we received from industry were impracticable. The submission that gave us most concern related to a request that rights of appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal be granted in respect of certain discretions in the Bill. There is no doubt that there is a very great need for the right of appeal to be incorporated in the legislation at some time. Nevertheless, we were aware that the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, and particularly Senator Tate who is on that Committee, have made a very detailed submission on the rights of appeal in various areas of this legislation. Many of the points raised by Senator Tate were not covered by the industries' submissions and vice versa. We are also aware that the Administrative Review Council is looking at the whole area of discretions. It has yet to make its recommendations. For all these reasons it seemed to us to be unwise to introduce amendments which would tackle the right of appeal in an ad hoc way. However, we stress, as Senator Evans stressed, the need for the Government to look at this matter. We believe the rights of individuals can be stamped upon by too much Executive responsibility. The rights of appeal must be looked at and we look forward to the Government's assurance in that area.

It is significant that the former Bureau had been operating under the existing legislation for over 14 years and that in fact there have been very few complaints. This aspect was taken into account in our final decision not to proceed with any requests or amendments to this legislation. We believe it is important that it has a speedy passage through this chamber. As I said earlier, there is an urgent need for a tightening of the whole administrative procedures of Customs. They are under great pressure. We welcome the Government's efforts in this area. We can only hope that the obvious problems that exist in the Service at the moment will continue to receive the Government's urgent and careful attention and that we can look forward to a series of Bills in relation to Customs matters which will give effect to a streamlining of the whole Customs area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very early this week I determined that I would cast my eye over the order of business and find an opportunity to talk on the Costigan report. I have found my opportunity. Before the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) despairs, I say that it is only a sort of catalyst to some wider-ranging remarks I wish to make. I refer to paragraph 12 of chapter 10 of the report of the Royal Commissioner, Mr Costigan. After he described the various levels of criminal enterprise which operate in Australia Mr Costigan came to what one might call the base group which he largely identified with the painters and dockers. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The final group consists of the criminals who execute the schemes. They may be called upon to man the hotels as SP bookmakers. They may be asked to distribute drugs, or to fire the gun, or use the cosh. It is they who move the containers, or remove from them the contraband, . . .

That gives me my opening. I repeat: 'It is they who move the containers, or remove from them the contraband'. The Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs which reported on 21 December 1979 was conducted by the honourable Mr Justice Williams, as honourable senators will recall. In the report of that Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs one reads of the concern of the Commissioner that in fact there had been a movement of drugs into Australia by way of cargo coming into the country without sufficient or adequate surveillance by the then Bureau of Customs. For example, at page A209 he said:

Many witnesses drew attention to the potentiality for smuggling through cargo, especially in containerised cargo. The volume of all types of cargo entering Australia, the size of individual containers and the need to facilitate cargo to consignees combine to give what some witnesses described as 'the perfect opportunity' to smuggle not only drugs but other types of illegal importations.

The Royal Commissioner details on that page and the few succeeding pages some instances which were brought to his attention in which on various waterfronts around Australia methods of Customs clearance were such that the weaknesses in them allowed contraband to come into Australia in a way which would not have been the case had Customs preventive measures been more assiduously and properly pursued. One reads in Book B of the report of the Royal Commissioner some recommendations as to ways in which the entry into Australia of these undesired goods might be prevented. He makes a recommendation at page B170. I remind the Senate that I am speaking of a report of 21 December 1979. I think it became a parliamentary paper in March 1980. A recommendation of the Royal Commissioner made all those years ago stated:
Customs legislation relating to cargo should be amended as follows:

A new section be inserted into the Customs Act to provide that no goods shall be brought into Australia in a cargo container unless such a container has been sealed with a seal or fastener approved by the Comptroller-General and all such seals and fasteners are marked with an individual identifying number which is recorded on all documents presented to obtain Customs clearance of the container and its contents.
He stated further:

A new section be inserted into the Customs Act to provide that any person who takes delivery of a container which has its seal or fastener broken or altered or otherwise tampered with must notify a Collector of Customs immediately of that fact. It should be an offence to open, alter, make, break, tamper, or otherwise deal with a container seal without the authority in writing of the Collector.

Despite the fact that those manifestly desirable recommendations were made by Mr Justice Williams almost three years ago there is, to my great disappointment, nothing in this legislation which provides for the sealing or fastening of containers in the way which he recommended. There can be little doubt, as one reads the various royal commission reports, that the entry into Australia of drugs, arms and ammunition by this means is such that one would have expected those recommendations to be taken up.

One finds, indeed, that the Auditor-General in his report of September 1982-it has just been made available to honourable senators in recent days-said in his commentary on the Department of Industry and Commerce that he conducted an audit in Queensland and Western Australia which revealed control weaknesses which impaired the effectiveness of the cargo control system. He went on to generalise from his audit of Western Australia and Queensland districts about the situation which obtained throughout Australia. I remind honourable senators that this report was presented some three years after Mr Justice Williams indicated the necessity for the institution of proper issue and use of cargo container seals. Under the heading 'Cargo Control' the Auditor-General stated:

Cargo containers are normally sealed by companies or agents responsible for loading at overseas ports. The seals should remain intact until the containers are released from Customs control. However, instances were noted where:
the resealing of a container was carried out by a pest control company following fumigation
broken seals were replaced by shipping companies, and
seals were attached with tape to the container door.

As the issue and use of seals are outside the control of Customs and if the system is to be relied upon, an assessment is necessary of the effectiveness of the control over seals exercised by the companies and agents.
The Auditor-General went on to have a look at the process of checking seals. He said:
Although departmental procedures require the checking of seals, these were not always carried out effectively. It was observed that during a routine check carried out by Customs officers:
the seals on the containers selected for detailed inspection were not checked prior to the release of the container, and
the seal was not intact when the officers arrived at the consignee's premises after the container was delivered, but no further action was taken.

Page after page then follows of the Auditor-General's comments on the lack of security over containers, the lack of control checks and the release of consignments, as I said earlier, without the proper individual surveillance of their contents. As I said, there are three or four pages of such details in the Auditor-General's report. At page 51 of the report, the Auditor-General concluded:
The revenue and other implications of failures to adhere to satisfactory Cargo Control and Accounting procedures are extremely serious.

It may be said that very little has been done in these last three years-in fact, nothing has been done-to follow up the suggestions of Royal Commissioner Williams on this matter. No doubt this also formed the basis for many of Mr Costigan's observations that criminal elements were using the waterfront, particularly the containerised system, to move drugs and other illicit articles into Australia. Nothing has been done in those three years. It may be said that nothing can be done because we are awaiting some international convention to be brought into effect to allow government seals to be attached at the ports of dispatch and that it is only through a system of government seals being instituted and internationally recognised that one will be able to control the problem sufficiently.

I do not think that it is a sufficient answer. It obviously was not seen as a sufficient answer by Mr Justice Williams or the Auditor-General. When there are instances of company seals attached overseas being obviously tampered with and this not being followed up in a sufficiently diligent manner by our own Customs officers then there is great cause for concern. In fact, I think one could reasonably conclude that damage to revenue and to our whole social fabric has been as serious as the Auditor-General indicates. As an ordinary back bencher I feel there may be a deficiency in the Bill. As a member of the Opposition I hope that the Bill will have a fairly speedy passage. Insofar as it increases substantially the penalties provided for contraventions of the Act and makes some amendments, it is welcome.

The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has had a look at the Bill. It came to the conclusion that it would not pursue a matter which it was alerted to by a consideration of the Bill but which affects the Act as a whole. The Committee made the general comment that while section 273GA of the Customs Act provided for certain specific decisions to be subject to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, only limited rights of appeal are generally available under the Act. The Committee indicated that a number of provisions in the present Bill were not subject to rights of appeal. For example, it looked at amendments included in clauses 7, 12, 14 and 32. It further pointed out that clauses 18 and 25 propose the vesting of non-appealable discretions in the Minister by amendments to sections 83 and 108 of the Act respectively, although appeals under these sections were available against decisions by the Comptroller -General or Collector of Customs. The fact is that the question of appeals against decisions under the Customs Act is presently under review by the Administrative Review Council. Therefore, it was decided that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee would not press amendments or suggestions in relation to the individual provisions.

The Committee wrote to the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) drawing his attention to the matter, and the Minister was courteous enough to reply to the Committee. I must say that this relationship which is growing between the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and Ministers is entirely to be welcomed. I am sure that honourable senators would agree that the role of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee is much enhanced if indeed as a result of the circulation of the Alert Digest the Executive enters into discussion with a view to trying to meet the points made by the Committee in those Alert Digests.

The Minister, in his response, made the point that the provisions to which we referred were basic to the discharge of Customs responsibilities, crucial to the exercise of effective control by Customs and directed to the prevention of the introduction of undesirable imports and the erosion of revenue. That view has been put by the Government to the Administrative Review Council in its submission. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee and, I suggest, the chamber perhaps ought to await the report of the Administrative Review Council in order to come to a balanced and responsible conclusion as to the desirability of some appeal mechanism. It would be unfortunate if, in pursuing the particular right that we might say ought to inhere in people who are affected by decisions under the Customs Act, we were to risk the erosion of revenue or the importing of undesirable goods into this country. Obviously some balance ought to be struck, and with this matter under review by the Administrative Review Council I think the chamber can have some confidence that that report will be such as will enable us as senators to draw sensible and practical conclusions as to the type of amendments that might then be moved to incorporate some further rights of appeal if they are thought to be desirable. I would think as to particular clauses it might well be that during the Committee stage some remarks by members of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee might then be made.As to the Bill as a whole, certainly the Opposition wishes it a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Opposition and the Australian Democrats for their general support of the Bill. Several matters were raised by Senators Evans, Tate and Siddons. A number of them were repetitive but I will endeavour to address one or two of the major points. First, Senator Evans sought some further information in connection with the restructuring of the Australian Bureau of Customs. He referred to the media statement last Sunday made by the Acting Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Fife, in connection with the new arrangements for the formation of the Australian Customs Service.

SPEECH.PARA: I should point out that this important step is the culmination of almost five years of development work involving departmental staff, staff associations and the Public Service Board. During late 1977 and early 1978 the inspection concept was developed and formally submitted to the Public Service Board in April 1978. This concept was the basic factor in the whole restructuring exercise. It proposes a single employment category of Customs officers. Detailed consultations commenced with staff associations in December 1980 and have continued until recently, with all associations now advising agreement to the implementation. Their suggestions were all carefully considered and where appropriate were adopted. The new organisation will lead to the upgrading of Customs controls in accordance with government policies in relation to industry and community protection. I hope also that that substantially will answer some of the major concerns mentioned by Senator Tate in his remarks.

Furthermore, Senator Evans referred to the creation of the Service in a little more detail and drew attention to the fact that this appeared to be some kind of response to recent events. I should draw his attention to the ministerial statement made by the Honourable Neil Brown, Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs at the time, on 'Review of Customs Administration'. This statement was, I think, tabled in the House of Representatives in about April of this year. On page 2 of the statement Mr Brown said:

In this respect I inform the House that a great deal of work has already been completed by the Department and the Public Service Board on a major restructuring of the Customs organisation throughout the Commonwealth. The proposed restructuring includes the introduction of a single work category of Customs Officer which should lead to the elimination of work demarcation tensions now present. The Australian Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drugs recommended the early introduction of a single work category.

I draw the Senate's attention to that statement because it does, I think, make the point that this matter has been under consideration for a considerable time. It addresses itself to some of the problems and difficulties which I think Senator Tate foresaw and was referring to in his remarks.

Senator Evans furthermore drew attention to the fact that Mr A. G. Mayhew, a senior preventive officer, grade 1, in the Sydney office of the Department, had recently decided to retire. I thought for the record that it would be useful if the Senate had the benefit of a statement on this matter. I make the following points. Mr Mayhew did in fact have a discussion, at his request, with the Collector of Customs in New South Wales on 24 June 1982 during which he expressed concern about his health and talked about possible retirement. He was advised to see his own doctor. He did that and apparently on the next day produced a medical certificate from his doctor which suggested retirement. An appointment was made for Mr Mayhew to be examined by a Commonwealth medical officer in Sydney. Following that examination, the Commonwealth medical officer arranged for Mr Mayhew to see a specialist. The specialist subsequently reported to the Commonwealth medical officer who recommended to the Department that Mr Mayhew was unfit for continued employment and should be retired on medical grounds. Mr Mayhew was advised of the Commonwealth medical officer's report and that a declaration in terms of the Commonwealth Employees (Redeployment and Retirement) Act had been signed stating that he could not reasonably be employed in the Department because of his physical incapacity. His rights of appeal against that decision were notified to him. A recommendation for Mr Mayhew's retirement was then made to the Public Service Board's regional office in Sydney which, under the Act, has the responsibility of determining whether, in the light of the medical evidence, retirement is warranted. Mr Mayhew waived his rights of appeal against the declaration and indicated that he had no objection to retirement on invalidity grounds. It is understood that an officer of the Public Service Board discussed Mr Mayhew's proposed retirement with him last week. At the moment, the Department is awaiting a decision from the Public Service Board. Mr Mayhew has been on continuous sick leave since 25 June and has indicated that, if his invalidity retirement is approved, he would like it to be effective from 1 October.

Senator Siddons referred to matters of concern, which were referred to by Senator Evans and Senator Tate, in connection with representations made by various organisations in respect of the lack of review and appeal rights in the legislation. Some assertions were made that the Government had made no attempt to answer those representations. I understand the situation to be that the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, did reply to those representations from the organisations mentioned by Senator Siddons, albeit perhaps at a time subsequent to the debate in the House of Representatives on the Customs and Excise Amendment Bill. So, in that sense, no discourtesy was intended in respect of dealing with those submissions from the various organisations. In fact, all due consideration was given to them.

Senator Evans made the point that the Government appeared to be of the mind that it would be inappropriate for review procedures to be installed in the Act. That is not so. Indeed, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, which was referred to by Senator Tate, at paragraph 5 on page 2 of its report drew attention to the fact that the Administrative Review Council was continuing its review of the appeal provisions and that the relevant department had made submissions to the Council in relation to this Bill. The Committee drew these matters to the attention of the Senate for information. It seems to me that, in the light of the fact that this matter is before the ARC for consideration at the present time, a number of matters need to be take into account. The action which has been flagged by Senator Siddons on behalf of the Australian Democrats, and I believe by Senator Evans in his general comments, that we should allow that process to develop so that we can obtain further information from that august body as to its views on the matter in this area is the appropriate action to take. Before regulations will be set up under this legislation, industry and various industry organisations will be consulted before their finalisation. Consequently there will be an opportunity for views to be taken on board, which I think was the expression used by Senator Siddons.

Senator Evans made one further point in relation to the restructuring of the Department of Industry and Commerce and was very interested to obtain further information. This is a matter on which I will need to refer to the Minister to obtain his clearance. I understand the position to be that the Public Service Board is currently reviewing the matter and is getting close to finalising its views on the representations made by the Department. Subsequent upon that it would be feasible for the Government to make information upon the restructuring available to the Parliament. I undertake to refer those questions to the Minister and to see whether there might be something more than can be said in that regard.

Senator Tate made several points in relation to containerised cargo. It is relevant to note that increased resources have been made available to examine cargo and that new procedures have been operating from 15 March this year. Tightened controls have been implemented over the movement of containerised cargo. There is also an increased intelligence capability in Customs to assess risk and to determine possible targets in this area. It is physically impossible -I believe Senator Tate would agree with me-to review, sight and check all containers. Senator Tate drew our attention to the use of seals. One would have to say that seals would be of questionable value in Customs control, particularly when one has regard to the fact that it would be the responsibility of the shipping companies to put the seals on the containers. I understand that currently an international study is occurring in Brussels in order to determine the role of Customs and the use of seals in this area.

Another matter which Senate Tate mentioned concerned the Auditor-General's report and that the points raised in the report only became public in the last week or so. The Government is considering these matters. I thank honourable senators for their general support of the legislation. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 17 of the Customs and Excise Amendment Bill deals with the conditions which apply in relation to warehouse licences. I record the fact that in private submissions to the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills the attention of the Committee was drawn to section 82 of the principal Act which clause 17 seeks to amend. It was put to the Committee that an amendment might be made to the existing provision so that the obligation falling on a warehouse licence holder to notify the Collector if a person participating in the management or control of a warehouse were convicted of a prescribed offence or became bankrupt should arise only if the licence holder had reasonable grounds for knowing that such a conviction or bankruptcy had occurred.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe Senator Siddons and Senator Evans have already commented on whether that would be a practicable type of amendment to make to section 82 (1) of the principal Act. The Committee did take up the matter with the appropriate Minister. We sought his advice and received a reply which led us to the conclusion that the Committee should draw the existing provision to the attention of this chamber for its information but should not itself make any particular proposal as to the desirability of amending the principal Act in the way that was sought to be done. We did so on the very clear understanding that the undertaking by the Minister was that section 82 would be caught up in an ongoing review of the provisions of the Customs Act. We take that to mean something more specific than merely the general review which is maintained over any Act which a Minister or department is required to administer and that, in fact, some specific attention will be given in the near future to that submission concerning section 82 (1).
We were also concerned with clause 17 (c), which inserts into section 82 (2) an ability to prescribe regulations. Section 82 (2) presently reads:
A warehouse licence is subject to such other conditions, if any, as are prescribed.

The clause seeks to insert in section 82 (2) the purposive words 'for the protection of the revenue, for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the Customs Acts or otherwise'. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee was concerned to get from the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) some understanding of what the words 'or otherwise' mean because if the warehouse licence is to be subject to conditions which are prescribed otherwise than for the protection of the revenue or otherwise than for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the Customs Act, it seems a very odd circumstance that such regulations could properly be made. It seems that a very open charter is being given to the prescriber of the regulations. I must say that I found the response by the Minister to be somewhat unsatisfactory. The Minister made this point:

The expression 'or otherwise' has been included because requiring something to be done or observed in a particular way in respect of goods which fall into that statutory category of 'goods which are subject to the control of the Customs' may not be regarded, in the stricter sense, as requiring 'compliance with the Customs Act'.
To be quite frank, I find it very difficult to comprehend the meaning of that paragraph. The Minister went on to say:

Due regard should be had also to the fact that the provision being amended does not relate to discretionary exercise of powers but is one authorising the prescribing of regulations. The overriding regulation-making power in section 270 of the Customs Act authorises the making only of regulations that are not inconsistent with the Act.

That is complete and utter balderdash. It is a fact that we are dealing here with a regulation-making power. If the Minister had gone on to say 'and therefore the Regulations and Ordinances Committee will have an opportunity to look at the product of that regulation-making power' and that in itself provides some effective safeguard against the misuse of this power which, as I say, seems to have a very open charter by the addition of the words 'or otherwise', I could have grasped it and understood what is intended. But to say that somehow section 270, in authorising the making of regulations that are not inconsistent with the Act, somehow overrides or controls the proposed new section 82 (2) is completely and utterly wrong because the proposed new section 82 (2) becomes something consistent with the Act.
The fact is that we now have a situation where conditions may be attached to warehouse licences. As I say, section 82 (2) will read:
A warehouse licence is subject to such other conditions, if any, as are prescribed for the protection of the revenue, for the purpose of . . . the Customs Act or otherwise.

This is an extremely wide charter. There is no way in which section 270 inhibits , restricts or controls what may be done in the prescribing of those regulations . Indeed, the only safeguard is the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee. I assure the Minister and the Department that the Committee will be very astute in examining what might emerge from an exercise of that regulation-making power.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Tate obviously has an advantage over most of us in having had very detailed discussions on these matters with the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch). I am only able to reiterate the Minister's views as established in the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I indicate that there is a general need to ensure the widest possible opportunity for the Department of Industry and Commerce to enforce its rights rather than to have them limited to a degree by relying purely and simply on words written in black and white in the legislation. Because of that, I believe the slightly wider context of the phrase used by the Minister is in fact appropriate. But in the light of Senator Tate's concern and continuing worries about this matter, I believe it would be appropriate naturally for him to raise the matter further with the Minister. Clearly, there are always ongoing reviews of this kind. As he would know, the Minister will also be considering other matters in relation to this consequent upon any later reports by the Administrative Review Council or whatever. I wonder whether Senator Tate will accept for the time being the proposition that we will endeavour to raise his concerns with the Minister and establish a basis for later discussion between him and the Minister on this point.

—As I have already indicated, the Opposition will not press any amendment at the Committee stage because it wants to see the passage of this legislation as speedily as practicable. But I make the point that at the moment the wording of section 82 (2) restricts by implication the imposing of conditions to those conditions which are consistent with achieving the purposes of the Customs Act. That is just a normal piece of statutory construction. But the amendment obviously goes much further than that in putting in purposive words which go much further than saying 'for the purpose of ensuring compliance with the Customs Act' and which are in my view unnecessary when it goes on to say 'or otherwise'. Perhaps I would have my mind set at ease if the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), or the Minister in consultation with his advisers, could give me an example of what must have been in the minds of the advisers, the Department or the Minister when it was felt necessary to add those words? What sort of conditions might be attached to a warehouse licence other than those necessary for the protection of the revenue or to ensure compliance with the Act?

—I am advised that an example in an area that might interest Senator Tate is duty free shops. Apparently a question could arise in relation to the way in which goods are displayed and advertised in this area. For that reason, the Government seeks some extension, as outlined in the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That has set my mind greatly at ease. I think I ought to comment on clause 19 because really it involves a matter of some importance in the history of the proceedings of the Parliament. Clause 19 deals with the suspension of warehouse licences. It is pleasing to see the flexibility of the Minister and of the Government in acknowledging a point well made and in making the necessary change in the Bill's passage through the Parliament.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows--

As announced in the Budget Speech, the Government has decided on two sales tax changes. Legislation for one of them-an increase of 2.5 percentage points in existing rates-has just been introduced. The Bill I am now introducing deals with the second aspect and will impose sales tax of 7.5 per cent on a range of goods that are now exempt from the tax. This extension of the sales tax base will have effect on goods that pass the taxing point-normally the last wholesale sale-on or after 1 January 1983.

I drew attention last year to the clear advantage that lies in effecting some change in the mix of direct and indirect taxes. I again emphasise the potential that such a change generates for desirable reductions in direct taxes, particularly personal income tax. The technical effect of the Bill will be to tax at 7.5 per cent, on and after 1 January 1983, goods which are at present exempted by items 53, 58, 105, 107 and 113F, sub-items (4), (5A), (6), (7) and ( 10) of item 120 and item 120A in the first schedule. The broad classes of goods which fall within the scope of the items other than 113F are maps, hand tools, motion picture films, household drapery and soft furnishings, cleaning and polishing cloths, braid, ribbon and tape, blankets, handkerchiefs and cleaning sponges and engine-cleaning cotton waste. The goods covered by item 113F are, very broadly, servicing equipment and construction equipment. More particularly, this equipment covers servicing equipment used to service, repair or recondition motor vehicles, aircraft, ships or railway rolling stock or in retreading and repairing of tyres and repairing of footwear for human wear. The item also covers equipment used for constructing, maintaining or repairing buildings or other structures, or roads, dams, pipelines, drains, trenches, tunnels or other works.

I should emphasise that this item deals with equipment, et cetera which is used in the course of servicing, repair or construction as the case may be. It does not include goods which become part of the goods being repaired or the structures being built. Using buildings as an example, equipment for use in contruction of a building will become taxable at 7.5 per cent but the materials used to construct the building and that thereby become part of the building will remain exempt from sales tax. I emphasise that goods falling within any of these categories will still be exempt from sales tax if they are sold in circumstances in which an overriding exemption in the first schedule to the Sales Tax ( Exemptions and Classifications) Act applies. Similarly, where a manufacturer purchases such goods for use as 'aids to manufacture', the goods will remain exempt under the 'aids to manufacture' head of exemption. I do not think that I need to go into greater detail at this stage. As usual, however, an explanatory memorandum covering technical aspects of the Bill is being made available to honourable senators and this provides details of the goods affected by these measures. The net result of the changes will be an increase in revenue estimated at some $44m in 1982-83 and $105m in a full year. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
