SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Plant Variety Rights Bill 1982 on which I will continue my remarks. It seems to me that the present restriction on access to overseas varieties stems directly from an absence of plant variety rights legislation in Australia. The reason for this is perhaps best described by a well-known writer, Bert Kelly-'The Modest Farmer' -who wrote in the Bulletin in 1980:

SPEECH.PARA: We could import them (new varieties) but this is difficult if we have not passed the PVR legislation because people in countries with this legislation are usually unwilling to send us their new varieties because we could then turn around and sell our material back to their country in competition with them.

I would add to that only that no businessman will voluntarily place at risk the very product which is his source of income. In the case of plant breeding the product is the seed which he is seeking to protect. There is an abundance of evidence, of course, that the absence of PVR legislation restricts access to overseas varieties. It ought to be emphasised that the frustration of Australian farmers and nurserymen is being compounded by the tremendous advances in productivity that are being made in many countries that presently enjoy PVR legislation.

A recent study by Mrs Silvey of the British National Institute of Agricultural Botany, published in the Institute's annual journal, is worthy of note. The study is very interesting in that it states that in the period between 1947 and 1977 the wheat yield in England and Wales had increased by approximately 94 per cent and the barley yield by 67 per cent which, in the case of wheat, is an increase from 2.4 tons per hectare to over 4.7 and in the case of barley from 2. 3 tons per hectare to 3.8 tons. Analysis of that empirical data also shows that of the 94 per cent yield increase in wheat, 56 percentage points was as a result of improved varieties. In the case of the barley yield, 32 per cent of the 67 per cent was the result of improved varieties.

Whilst I would not seek to claim that the increased yield directly attributable to improved varieties was solely the result of PVR legislation-it is clearly not -what has occurred is that the PVR has provided a massive stimulus for plant breeding which necessarily ensures improved varieties. This is shown by the fact that almost half of the yield increases over the 30-year period have occurred in the last 10 years when the United Kingdom was enjoying PVR legislation. It is principally because of the productivity increase effect of PVR legislation that so many countries have introduced such legislation. When one looks at the list, which includes the United Kingdom, the Netherlands, Denmark, West Germany, Austria, Belgium, France, Switzerland, Spain, Italy, Sweden, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Poland, Romania, Russia, South Africa, New Zealand, Israel, Japan and the United States of America, one is left with a feeling that Australia and Australians are being left behind.

A great many farmers have written to me expressing concern about the plant variety rights legislation because they have not clearly understood the public debate. They wanted to know how it would operate and how it would effect them. They sought information about accusations that have been made relating to multinationals and takeovers. For those people the proposed scheme can best be explained by way of an example. For the purpose of this explanation I will look at the way PVR will affect wheat growers. The first aspect that should be considered is the patenting of the seed. When a plant breeder produces a seed he may apply for registration. Of course, it must be emphasised that registration is not compulsory; it is certainly optional.

Let us assume that a breeder has produced a new variety of wheat seed. In order to obtain registration he must first satisfy the basic criteria under the Bill. These criteria are that the cultivar must be new, distinct, uniform and stable. It is worth stopping for a moment to consider the implications of these criteria . So far as the newness is concerned, this means that the variety must not have been grown commercially in the country of origin. From a wheat grower's point of view, he can totally ignore the new PVR system if he so wishes and chooses and he can continue to grow the same wheat without being in the slightest way affected by the provisions of the new Bill. It is only when he is interested in growing a new variety that has been registered that the PVR legislation will affect him.

The criterion for distinctiveness requires that the new variety differ from all known varities in one or more important botanical or agronomical characters. In some respect, this is superfluous because no wheat grower will buy a seed at a higher cost if it is in no way different from the one he is presently using. The other two characteristics of uniformity and stability are fairly self- explanatory Having satisfied these criteria, a breeder must then apply for registration which, under the Bill, requires the agreement of the Australian Agricultural Council which of course comprises State and Federal Ministers for Primary Industry. It is perhaps worth noting that feature of the Bill for a moment to highlight the fact that the Agricultural Council will not give its consent to the registration of a new variety which is not generally supported by the industry and the various groups associated and interested in this area.

Once a breeder has satisfied all of those requirements, and provided he is not challenged by a person lodging an objection under clause 17 of the Bill, he is then granted a patent which entitles him to the exclusive right-subject to safeguards which I will come to later-to sell that new variety. The wheat grower can thus consider the advantages and disadvantages of buying the new seed, as he chooses. It is in many ways similar to investing in a new stud bull. If you want higher productivity and better quality, and therefore a profitable return on your investment, you can obviously purchase, at a higher price, the new variety. But that choice, the assessment of whether it is in the grower's commercial interest to purchase the new variety, is left solely to the grower. There is no compulsion whatsoever to purchase.

Let us assume that the grower, having been impressed with the results obtained from studies carried out on the new variety, decides to buy the cultivar, sows the seed and harvests the crop. What happens then? First, he is entitled to sell his wheat regardless of anything in the plant variety rights legislation, subject of course to the requirements of the Australian Wheat Board. Secondly, he is entitled to re-sow the seeds of the harvest, use the grain for feeding stock or for any other purpose, regardless of anything in the legislation. It is only when the grower wants to sell the seeds of the harvest-and, of course, the actual seeds purchased from the breeders-that he may do so only in accordance with the terms of sale of the seed by the breeder to the grower. It is the right to control the sale of the seed, though not its use, that the Bill, in clause 32 , protects.

However, should a breeder unreasonably restrict the sale of a variety, and not take steps to ensure that the reasonable requirements of the public in respect of that plant variety are satisfied, the Bill vests in the Secretary to the Department the right to license other breeders to produce that variety, so the first breeder loses his protection. That is not something that, in my view, any breeder would take lightly.

The other major concern of the farming community and the nurserymen is the accusation that PVR legislation will lead to takeovers of plant breeding companies and, ultimately, control by multinational fertiliser companies of plant breeding. It is true that nothing in the Bill prevents company takeovers, which often occur in the free market and in that respect have nothing to do with PVR legislation per se. The experience in the United Kingdom has suggested that in any event these concerns are ill-founded. In Britain in 1977 there were 15 companies breeding vegetables, 47 breeding agricultural crops, 20 breeding decoratives and three breeding fruit. And this, it should be remembered, is after more than 15 years experience of PVR legislation in that country. Protection against attempts to monopolise the plant breeding market is also afforded by sections 45 to 50 of the Trade Practices Act.

Another view that is put by the opponents of PVR is that if multinational fertiliser companies gain control of plant breeding they will produce seeds which will require their fertilisers and which are more susceptible to a wipe- out. This is simply not true because, firstly, farmers are not going to buy such seeds and, secondly, the Australian Agricultural Council would not agree to their registration.

Similarly, the accusation that PVR will lead to genetic erosion is not sustainable. Genetic erosion may occur with or without PVR legislation and the stimulation given to the plant breeding industry in Australia would ensure an even greater genetic diversity. Certainly, the National Seed Storage Laboratory at Fort Collins, Colorado, which holds more than 380,000 varieties of seeds, in a country which has enjoyed PVR for some time, supports the view that genetic erosion will not occur as a result of PVR.

One other point that I wish to make is that I am surprised that PVR legislation has encountered opposition from conservationists, because the increase in plant breeding may well see the development of varieties of seeds whose cultivation requires less pesticide and herbicide such as 2,4,5-T and 2,4-D. Such seeds, attractive as they are to farmers, both for their comparative cost savings and environmental impact, may be one of the first of the new progeny developed under PVR legislation.

In addition, it should be noted that the cost of seeds produced and registered under PVR, to those growers who voluntarily choose to buy them, will be relatively small. Currently, the average royalty payment on seeds of protected United States wheat varieties is only 50c a bushel and, in the case of oats, only 30c. In 1978 in the United Kingdom, where PVR also operates, wheat seed was selling for the Australian equivalent of $12 a bushel, of which the royalty component was 65c or 5.4 per cent of the purchase price. The total cost to the Government of this whole proposal is estimated as approximately $50,000 per annum-hardly significant in the context of an overall Government expenditure of $42 billion.

I should like to conclude by referring the Senate to the question of monopolies and the stand by multinationals. I am reminded of the following statement made by Senator Childs in the Senate on this subject on 8 September:

Perhaps the most sinister aspect of plant patents is that they are being pushed by huge multinational corporations which also have large interests in insecticides, fertilisers and other chemicals. I make no apology for criticising multinational companies such as Shell Oil, Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz because they are typical of the companies involved. There will be two problems. These companies will make sure that the seeds which develop are dependent on their chemicals. This has happened in the United States of America. The very size and concentration of the industry could endanger agricultural diversity.

There seems to be some conflict, confusion and debate within the Australian Labor Party itself. In that regard, I refer the Senate to comments made at an earlier date by one of Senator Childs's colleagues, who said:

The second fallacy proposed by the Lygon Street farmers is that if any plant variety rights legislation were passed all farmers would be forced to buy seeds from the monopolists, who would soon gain control of seed production. That is wrong because most farmers keep their own seed and would be able to continue doing so. They could also keep indefinitely the seed of the varieties they are already growing. A refinement of the multinational conspiracy theory is that these monopolists, who are assumed to be multinationals, I suppose to increase the scare power of the theory, would then devote all their attention to producing hybrid seeds which would germinate or ripen only if they were treated with vast quantities of poisonous chemicals. That was supplemented frequently by allegations that as soon as plant variety rights legislation was passed in the United States of America something like 365 small seed companies were taken over by the said multi- nationals in the space of about 15 minutes. I have been able to find absolutely no evidence to support that allegation.

I conclude by saying that I trust this legislation will find its way safely through the Senate today. There has been a suggestion that it be referred to a select committee. It seems to me that the public is slowly becoming tired of continual attempts by the Australian Democrats and, in some cases, the Australian Labor Party, to refer anything that is remotely controversial to a committee. I suspect sometimes that the purpose is not to examine the content, value or virtue of the legislation but rather to give breathing time for certain honourable senators to study the direction of the winds of fortune and favour and make a determination, not upon the merits of legislation, but upon pragmatic political judgments. I hope that that will not be the fate of this legislation, which I recommend to the Senate. I trust it will have a speedy passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Keeffe Sen J.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to cover a number of points that certainly were not covered by my opponent, Senator Crichton-Browne. I would like to enlighten him concerning one or two points. I emphasise first that the determination of the Opposition to send this Bill to a standing committee-not a select committee-is in order to give everyone in the community an opportunity properly to debate the issue. It was in about 1971 that some people in this country began talking about creating a certain type of plant variety rights legislation. Over the last couple of years opposition to such legislation has certainly mounted in all quarters. I propose to quote from a couple of statements from quite reliable sources. They are not by people who might be looked upon by members of this conservative government as people without authority or any idea of what they are doing. They are reputable people whose arguments are well supported.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I wish to support without equivocation the amendment that Senator Walsh moved on behalf of the Opposition. My own view of the PVR legislation, in its present form, is that it is bad legislation and, if carried, would be very dangerous for this country. I am implacably opposed to it. The legislation has not been well handled by the Government at any stage. When it was first introduced in another place the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) was at great pains not to say too much about it. It was significant that he brought in his own amendments, which we considered to be completely inadequate. Our spokesman then moved a large number of amendments covering a wide range of the legislation.

One of the matters in regard to this legislation in which the Opposition is in direct conflict with the Government concerns those who planned the legislation. After all, it was not planned by this Government. It has been forced on the Government by the transnational organisations who want to get their sticky little fingers onto the whole future of plant breeding in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sticky big fingers.

—That is right. They are determined to do it, so the Minister who introduced the Bill in the first place was put under great pressure by these organisations. We ought to remember first of all that seeds and all other forms of genetic material are not the playthings of individuals, single organisations or groups of powerful organisations. They should always remain a public resource and should always remain the property of the people. The seeds of the earth are a common heritage and as such should be treated with that sort of respect. Our generation relies on a great deal of its food coming from the earth. Indirectly we obtain our protein through eating beef and similar types of food, and we need the growing things to sustain the stock that we use to produce beef, milk, butter and what have you.

SPEECH.PARA: The plant variety rights legislation will encourage the narrowing of the genetic base of common plant varieties. From memory, a Mexican farmer came under very severe restriction because of the narrowing variety of seeds that he could buy. They produced a sturdy plant but one which would not stand up to the plant diseases and pests that the normal hardy plant will stand up to. He eventually found that a new type of moth had bred and his tomato crop was completely eaten away. He then found from the same agrochemical company from which he bought his seed that he had to buy a type of pesticide to dispose of the moths. Finally, he decided that if he did not get out of the whole show altogether the moths would eventually eat him. The farmers and other growers will be forced to pay royalties for seeds and plants, this will result in new taxes. I propose to enlarge on this in a few moments. The funding of the seed collection will bring up a new type of tax, as will the maintenance of seed banks and the administration of the plant variety rights legislation. All of this will place a charge on the people who make a living out of this industry and who provide the vegetables and other types of food that we eat.

In spite of what Senator Crichton-Browne said, foreign ownership of the Australian plant breeding and seed industry will be only a matter of time. If this legislation is passed this session, by the middle of next year inroads will have been made by the transnational companies. Already those companies are starting to make minor inroads into this particular industry. It will create injustice for those countries of the Third World from where most of the genetic material used in plant breeding comes. I think that has been mentioned in other places; certainly I referred to it in a story I wrote for a newspaper some time ago. Most of the plants of genetic purity are still to be found around the equator, where they have not been subject to an ice age. What might happen to our native flora? If the transnational companies get their hands on our flora they will breed from it and eventually sell it back to us.

There are many doubts about the value of PVR legislation. As recently as February this year Norway decided not to introduce it. Canada, like Australia, has had the matter hanging around for some time and the chances are that such legislation will not be introduced in that country either. Austria and Finland both have known or exclusive type plant patents but all they do is levy the royalties; they do not control the markets. Senator Crichton-Browne mentioned a number of countries, many of which are members of the European Economic Community. The EEC has ordered a study of the effects of plant variety rights legislation on its member states. I think this is to be carried out by a commissioner or commissioners. Let me refer to the United Kingdom legislation which is a little tighter than the American legislation, although America has gone cold on PVR. It has been trying to introduce amendments for a long time and unless it has happened in recent weeks, it has been unsuccessful. The Shell company in the United Kingdom now has control of 60 seed companies. Ten years ago it did not control one single company in the United Kingdom. It also has under its control 40 per cent of all the patented varieties and 50 per cent of all the barley varieties as of last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have they developed them or bought them?

—It does not matter what that company has done with them. The position is that 10 years ago Shell had no control over the seed industry at all . Now Shell and two other companies have 85 per cent of the packeted seed trade in the United Kingdom. Shell did not have that sort of control until it was assisted by plant variety rights legislation. That will occur here no matter what the honourable senator says. It may not necesssarily be that company but other companies with similar ambitions will do it.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Consumers Association has taken a very searching and critical view of the legislation. I propose shortly to quote some of its statements for the record. A coalition of a number of organisations, ranging from the Action for World Development group, through the Tasmanian Conservation Trust, the Food Justice Centre, Friends of the Earth, the Nature Conservation Council of New South Wales and the Queensland Conservation Council down to the Victorian Consumer Action Group, produced a paper in 1981. I am not sure of the exact date ; it was fairly late in the year. I want to quote two or three paragraphs from it. It said:

Foreign ownership of Australia's plant breeding and seed industry would be the result of Plant Variety Rights. This reputable group of organisations there contradicts the views of Senator Crichton-Browne.
The paper continues:
Plant Variety Rights would threaten the livelihoods of small seed merchants, and farmers, small seed growers and nursery persons.

Large scale enterprises with national and international marketing networks would benefit most from the proposed Plant Variety Rights scheme since it sets up the national co-ordination of plant and seed production and sales through the granting of monopoly rights. As in the present industrial patent system, most plant variety rights would be granted to overseas companies, thus laying the foundation for the foreign control of our major seed and plant markets.

Patents have been used in U.S.A. and Europe to mark out commercial territory in the seed and pharmaceutical industry. In the U.S.A. in any one crop a few companies own the majority of seed patents. The same form of market control would be exercised by foreign plantbreeding firms in Australia.

The rejection of Plant Variety Rights will not only make possible co-operative and sound plant breeding within Australia, but it will also give a great boost to Third World countries and international plant breeders who are increasingly becoming dissatisfied with the global effects of Plant Variety Rights and the priorities of those large corporations who are utilising P.V.R. to take up a dominant position in the world seed industry to the detriment of small farmers whose needs are overlooked.
The group's reference to native flora is in these words:
Native flora, the birthright of every Australia, must not be subject to Plant Variety Rights as allowed for by the Bill.
Those are the two or three paragraphs that I wanted to quote from that document.

Brian Chatterton, a member of the upper House in South Australia, the shadow Minister of Agriculture, Forests and Fisheries, wrote a very caustic letter to the Acting Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, in Canberra. He criticised in particular 'Plant Variety Rights-A Review of Issues', written by A . P. Ockawell and issued by the BAE as Paper No. 65. Most of us read this paper and I think that most of us were disgusted with the biased attitude of the paper in favour of the Bill.
Let me quote two or three paragraphs from Brian Chatterton's communication directed to the Acting Director of the BAE:
It can be seen that PVR countries performed worse than either of the other groups.
That was quoting a number of tables compiled by Mr Hollamby, the senior plant breeder at Roseworthy Agricultural College in South Australia. Mr Chatterton continued:

Mr Hollamby also showed that wheat yields in the U.K. had increased by 2% per year between 1947-77 due to genetic improvement with no discernible change in the rate since 1965 when P.V.R. was introduced in the U.K. By way of contrast Australian yield increases due to genetic improvement were .6% between 1945-65 but this rate has now risen to 2% per year due to improved technology by the same public breeders and without P.V.R.

On the question of seed costs, the B.A.E. has failed to look at the evidence and has failed to analyse the Australian scene. Seed costs in the U.S.A. have risen faster than any other agricultural input. Between 1967 and 1978 seed prices in the United States doubled and then doubled again.
That is precisely what will happen in Australia if the present Government is successful in putting this legislation into law. Mr Chatterton continues:

The price of lucerne seed rose from $22 a sack to $111. This is a faster rate of increase than petroleum products. In Australia the cost to farmers is likely to be even greater than the cost to European or United States farmers. The reason for this is that to make the system work the Australian farmers will have to be forced, persuaded or conned into purchasing seed. Australia has an ideal climate for seed production and currently most farmers produce their own seed. In South Australia less than 4 per cent of the wheat crop is sown with purchased seed.
In another part of the letter to the BAE-this is on page 11 of the report which I described earlier-this is Mr Chatterton's criticism:

The author seems to have made a very selective review of the effect of P.V.R. on the seed market. A different viewpoint was recently put in a well known journal on international development policy (New Internationalist February 1982) .

From a standing start in 1970 Shell Oil now markets seeds through at least 60 companies in Europe, North America, Latin America and Africa. It is by far the largest seed enterprise in the world. Close behind are two Swiss chemical twins Sandoz and Ciba-Giegy-with 22 and 30 companies respectively. Other European majors-none of whom appear to have been in the seed business a decade ago-are Sweden's Kema Nobel and Cardo; France's Elf Aquitaine and Rohne-Poulene, and Holland's Suike-Unie.
'It appears more than 400 firms have been either brought up or chased out over the past decade.'
Referring to page 18 of the report produced by the Department, Mr Chatterton continues:

The author claims that P.V.R. 'is analogous to the present system of patent laws which encourage invention by private firms and individuals.' This is a false analogy and shows a fundamental lack of understanding about the nature of plant breeding. Plant breeders invent nothing. They merely rearrange the genetic combination of existing common property plants. They do not create anything that does not already exist in the common property gene pool. Even the so-called genetic engineering is only a rearrangement of a more fundamental level of genetics. What is being done by P.V.R. is the granting of exclusive private property rights to a public common property resource. Naturally there are huge windfall profits to be made from this transfer of property rights just as there were in the past with the enclosure of the grazing commons or the granting of fishing authorities. It is hardly surprising that private companies should mount such an expensive campaign to try to capture these windfall profits.

I agree with that. I agree that the propaganda, or the so-called background papers produced by this Government, have all been aligned in a very biased way. It is quite surprising to see academics, mostly highly qualified people, producing information papers all biased in favour of the introduction of PVR legislation. No Government Department would do this unless it was being stood over by the Minister or by senior bureaucrats in the Department. In addition to that, they in turn have been stood over by the very people, companies such as Shell and others-I am not charging Shell with a takeover in Australia at present , although it will probably be highly interested-which have made this Government 's policy. I am surprised that Government senators are able to defend not the rights of the people of this country but the rights of the transnational organisations which want to control, with a handful of organisations, all the seed rights and everything else associated with agriculture.

The Australian Consumers' Association is a highly respectable organisation, the publisher of Choice and well-known for its outspokeness in criticising not only matters of this nature but many of our manufacturers, retailers and others who dare to do the wrong thing by the consumer. I shall read from several parts of the Press statement issued by the ACA. The Press release is entitled 'Consumers abused under PVR'. It says:

The rights to unique Australian flora-much of which has still to be named or discovered-could be lost to Australia overseas under the Federal Government's Plant Variety Rights Bill, the Australian Consumers' Association (ACA) has warned. The Association has stepped up its attack on the Bill, which is now before Parliament. In a major critique of the legislation--
This was issued in April 1982-
ACA has accused the Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Nixon, of excessive secrecy and of abdicating his responsibilities to Parliament over plant varieties rights (PVR).
It says there are no guarantees that PVR will be of any benefit to Australians. On the other hand, ACA says, the Bill will lead to:
* Extra expense for consumers and farmers;
* Abuse of consumer rights; and
* A decline in public plant breeding programs.

The Plant Variety Rights Bill would enable new varieties of plants or seeds to be patented, with royalties paid to the owners of the patent. The Bill has already been passed in the House of Representatives, despite widespread protests from consumer, conservation and horticulture and agriculture groups, and is scheduled for debate in the Senate this week.
That was negated. It was held over to this session of Parliament. The Press release continues:

On the threat to Australian flora, ACA says: 'This appears one of the worst aspects of PVR. Australian flora, much of which has yet to be named or discovered, could be patented under the legislation and hence potentially lost to overseas interests.'
ACA criticises Mr Nixon for his refusal to release his department's report on the introduction of PVR.

The association says one effect of the Bill will be a cut in government funds for agricultural research. Instead, it says, agriculture departments and other public bodies would be forced to patent new varieties in order to cover costs. This would mean consumers would pay twice for public research-once as taxpayers and again through royalties for patents. Farmers would pay three times if current levies were included.
ACA says it is appalled that Mr Nixon has abdicated his responsibilities to Parliament over PVR by giving the Australian Agricultural Council all authority over what varieties can be covered.
Mr Nixon had told Parliment that all discussions with the council were confidential and there would be no appeal against AAC decisions.
That means if environmentalists or farmers disagree about a particular genus- for example, wheat-being registered, there is no accessible appeal,'' ACA says.

The ACA has gone into great detail. It has analysed a number of aspects of the Bill. None of the analyses is favourable. One I want to quote relates to the protection of the public interest. The statement reads:

The prime concern of ACA is the complete disregard for consumers in this Bill. There is undue power resting with the Australian Agricultural Council and the administrators of the Act with the lack of an adequate appeals system. There is no guarantee that PVR would increase the quality of Australian agriculture.

Many months ago I asked a series of questions of the Minister. After a long period the replies came back. Most of them were impolite or polite evasions of the sense of the questions I placed on the Notice Paper. Others were virtually a repudiation of any information on particular matters. I agree with those who are critical that there has been undue secrecy. Pressures have been applied by people who have a vested interest in obtaining control of stocks of both plants and seeds in this country. I believe it will be in the best interests of those people-particularly consumers but also farmers, horticulturalists and others-who are now producing seeds and plants in a small or medium way to have the right to go before a public committee and state their case.

I have long been interested in growing plants in a very small way as an amateur gardener. I am interested in developing varieties. It is a long, painful and tiring process to develop a variety that will reproduce true to stock. In some cases it takes many years. It is exhilarating to see a plant experiment come out the right way. We will not have that sort of right any more. At the moment if I want to develop something I do not have to ask somebody whether I can do it. I do not want to sell the plants. At the moment I am allowed to give them as gifts to my friends so that they too can enjoy the experience of seeing a new type of flower blooming in their gardens. Those who need to make a living from this do have the right to sell their produce, but they will find themselves in the same situation as small developers and small breeders. They will not exist after about 18 months or two years. They will totally disappear. The big combines, the big transnationals, will then wave the big stick. They will decide what we shall eat and what we can grow.

The agricultural chemical companies are notorious for their development in this area in cases where they have had the opportunity to develop. Firstly, we must buy our seeds from them. The seeds are usually of poor quality and in some cases we probably would not be able to grow seed for the next crop so we have to go back and keep on buying their respective hybrids or whatever. Only they will be able to supply the right sort of fertiliser to look after their types of seeds. They will provide the pesticides to kill the moths and other bugs that get on to the plants they are selling. I think it will be a travesty if this legislation goes through. I hope we will get the opportunity to have it examined by the appropriate standing committee so that those people who are opposed to it and those who are in favour of it will be able to give their evidence in public and put up their case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have discussed with many groups the problems involved with plant variety rights legislation. I have discussed the matter with those who are in favour of it and those who are against it. After all the deliberations and discussions we have had, I must say that I have come down on the side which is in favour of plant variety rights. One reason is that I come from Tasmania, which is regarded almost as the vegetable garden for Australia. Tasmania is a significant producer of vegetables. Agriculture is terribly important not only to Australia's export economy but also to the total economy of Australia. To deny Australian agriculturalists the right to get the most up to date seeds available is to put Australian agriculture in a not very favourable position in relation to world trade.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that in this field, as in the industrial field, we must keep up to date. One of the tragedies of some of our secondary industries is that we have not kept up to date with modern developments. All too often management has been a little too tardy. We had an example recently with the steel industry and, unfortunately, the implications for employment there have been rather devastating. Therefore, I think that in the interests of the Australian economy, and in the interests of keeping agriculture to the forefront by developing the species that are needed, we must vote in favour of this plant variety rights legislation.

However, having recognised that, I must acknowledge that to some extent that is something of a selfish approach because, while we in the developed countries introduce this sort of legislation to protect our farmers and benefits and to produce the best crops so that we can maximise returns and raise our own standards of living, we add to cost structures. The benefits for us exceed that, otherwise we would not go in for it or we would not plant these sorts of things and instead stick to the traditional sorts of seeds. This increasingly puts the Third World countries in a fairly difficult situation because it raises their cost structures. It puts out of court their ability to get the sorts of seeds which they possibly need more than we do. The balance between producing the food of the world and the utilisation of the needs of people for food is a very delicate balance. There are all the problems of political intervention, drought, floods and famine. These sort of things make it very difficult.

From a humane point of view, I think the United Nations authorities and authorities such as that should devote some consideration to the impact that this sort of legislation-not only plant variety rights legislation but even patent rights legislation extending to industrial spheres-has on Third World countries. These are the areas with tremendous growth in population. Their needs are tremendous. They have tremendous difficulties. Therefore, I think that when we push through this legislation-I believe it is good for Australia-we should remember that it has world-wide implications. I believe we must give some sort of consideration to what we are going to do to those who are unable, for various reasons, to be able to get access to these sorts of seeds to feed their growing numbers. It is all very well to say that Australia, Canada and the United States of America will produce the grains to feed these people, but it is not as easy as that. In the Third World one can feed the indigenous population a lot easier if the food is grown by the people themselves because of the transport and political problems involved in getting food to such countries. I leave that matter for people's consideration.

The other factor I raise is that whenever we create a benefit as a result of legislation, which we are doing-we are creating a benefit for an identifiable group which develops a particular seed-inevitably we create a privilege for a group. Shortly after the PVR legislation was passed in the United Kingdom-within one week-either 74 or 84 seed companies or organisations were taken over by a very large group. I think we have to recognise that by passing legislation we will make that situation more attractive. I think that sometimes when we pass matters through the Senate we do not altogether realise the implications of the benefits and so on that we are passing on or denying. At the same time, this legislation has been around for a while. There has been a heck of a lot of discussion on it and a lot written about it. I doubt that by referring this matter to a standing committee of the Senate-I will be one of the senators sitting on that committee if the amendment is successful-we will add anything new to what is already known. As a lot of other speakers in this debate have said, this sort of legislation applies in most European countries, Japan, New Zealand and the United States.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on cable television is an enormous document. I must indicate that anything I have to say does not stem from a profound knowledge of all the matters contained in that report. I want to make some preliminary observations by way of indicating the Opposition's attitude to the early introduction of cable television in Australia. The Opposition thinks that the inquiry into cable television was somewhat premature. In fact, this Government even found itself in the extraordinary situation, as a result of the decisions made by a former Minister for Communications, of having a number of inquiries all going at once into aspects of broadcasting and telecommunications policy, many of which were inconsistent, one with the other.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal was asked to investigate the question of the introduction of cable television and radiated subscription television. The Davidson inquiry was asked to investigate the question of the privatisation of Telecom Australia. At the same time the satellite company AUSSAT was being set up with its own memorandum and articles of association which prescribed different functions. Of course, an inquiry was still going on at that stage into the Australian Broadcasting Commission. All of these things seem to us to be inconsistent, one with the other, and indicate appalling planning on behalf of the Government.

In connection with broadcasting policy the Opposition argues that what we need most is some consistency in the development of a system and some sense of direction about the development of the Australian broadcasting system. What is needed is some sort of orderly plan for development. There has certainly been no orderly plan for development enunciated by this Government in relation to the development of the broadcasting system and the communications system generally. What should have happened, of course, is that there should have been a general inquiry into the development of telecommunications in Australia not just a narrow inquiry into the privatisation of Telecom. If the Government had held a general inquiry into the future development of telecommunications then the question of the introduction of cable television might have been one of the terms of reference of such an inquiry.

If there were an orderly investment of the broadcasting system in Australia we would be able to build on the existing public investment in broadcasting and telecommunications. It is an enormous investment. It is not only a public investment but also a private investment. That is the context in which the question of cable television should be considered. What we have in government policy at the moment in broadcasting and communications is a degree of spasticity, if I can use that word, in which certain limbs of the system are doing things which are totally unrelated or unconnected in any logical sense to other limbs of the system. That is a sort of tragedy in the sense of the investment which is involved.

I would like to express a number of concerns and misgivings at this stage in relation to the early introduction of cable television in Australia. I want to itemise the misgivings of the Opposition. First of all, if one starts a cable television system in Australia one is talking about a very considerable investment whether that investment be by private enterprise or by government. The figures quoted for cabling the major capital cities in Australia vary from estimates of $3 billion down to $2 billion. The first question we have to ask is whether a country like Australia, which has a declining standard of living and an immense demand on resources, sees the development of cable television as a prime demand on available resources. The Opposition tends to argue that this is not so and that it is not a priority in terms of the use of resources in this country.

One of the sad things is that a body such as the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is not asked to consider, and of course has not the competence or the expertise to consider, the whole question of priorities in terms of other political, economic and social priorities which a government has to address. So in going about its deliberations the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal looks with a fair degree of tunnel vision at the question which is before it; namely, whether cable television would be a good and exciting thing to introduce into Australia without looking at these other broad questions of priority.

The first misgiving in respect of the report of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on cable and radiated subscription television is whether the time is ripe in terms of social and economic circumstances for the early introduction of cable television in Australia. The second misgiving we have relates very much to the question of technology. There is an existing technology available in terms of the use of co-axial cables which would, presumably, be used if there were an early introduction of cable television. However, the technology of optical fibres is already well developed. It is considered generally throughout the rest of the world to be a superior technology for transmission of cable television. By 1985, 1986 or 1987 there will be, I think, widespread use of the superior technology of optical fibres wherever cable television is introduced. So if Australia were, before then, to embark on the introduction of cable television, what it would be doing would be introducing an already superseded technology.

If we look at the situation in Great Britain, British Telecom has told manufacturers of co-axial cable in Britain that they will have no more orders from British Telecom after 1985, that British Telecom will be moving to optical fibres after 1985. If we look at the experience in the United States, in Alaska there are already pilot schemes using optical fibre technology in existence. So it would be wasteful and spendthrift indeed for Australia, at this stage, to introduce a superseded technology with cable television. The appropriate time to do these things is probably when Telecom Australia comes to the stage of replacing its existing cables in ducts which, really, run to most of the houses in most of the cities of Australia.

The other criticism we have of the report is the Tribunal's failure to reach a conclusion about the introduction of cable television and to distinguish between what engineers call the hardware-software separation; namely, that the best way for delivery of services is preferably to provide a system by a public authority , and to provide the information, the entertainment, the programming for that system from an alternative source. That is to say, the system itself should be separated from the source of the material that goes into it. The classic simple example of the software-hardware separation, of course, is the telephone. That is the most obvious example. The system is provided by a neutral authority; the use of the system is provided by input by various individuals and so on.

The so-called hardware-software separation is of immense importance in developing systems of any kind. It is essential in our view, if we are to have an orderly development of the Australian broadcasting system, that that very fundamental distinction be recognised; that we have a provider of the system which carries the signals or the messages and a distinct and quite different provider of the material which goes on to the system. That is what we do with our existing television. It is what we should do with cable television as well. It is most important, I think, that those sorts of distinctions be recognised.

Time eludes me. I merely wanted to indicate some preliminary misgivings and concerns about the technological romanticism which exists about the vast virtues of cable television. There are a number of points which I would be concerned to make which suggest that it would not be culturally desirable for this country to introduce a vast range of choice of television availability without adequate programming facilities to see that that choice is in fact a real one. We flag our concerns about this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are opposed to the early introduction of cable television. We made a submission along those lines to the inquiry into cable television. We are very concerned about its early introduction for a variety of reasons. Some of those reasons were referred to by Senator Button. We believe that it would be enormously expensive to introduce. In looking at experience in overseas countries, such as the United States of America, it is very significant to note that cable television is hardly viable, even in cities such as New York and Los Angeles. In fact, it has not been nearly as popular as was first anticipated. If these sorts of cities are finding trouble in making cable television viable, the investment of billions of dollars to introduce it into cities such as Melbourne and Sydney-and I suggest they are the only two cities in Australia where it could be even considered-is very suspect. So we are opposed to it on the grounds of economic viability and the enormous capital expenditure involved. Our priorities for investment should be directed to much more urgent projects.

SPEECH.PARA: Again, there is concern by the Australian Democrats that there are competing technologies in this area. For instance, satellite technology certainly impinges on cable television and many of the advantages of cable television can be achieved, to some degree, by satellite technology. In addition, we as a party are very much in favour of the early introduction of radiated subscription television. If we are to have radiated subscription television, that will not be viable if we at the same time introduce cable television. We believe that radiated subscription television would give us high quality programs in certain areas. It would give us access to top line films on television sets which people would be prepared to pay for. It would give us additional television channels which could be used for educational purposes at off-peak viewing times and it would, by and large, be a very minor investment with some quite considerable advantages to the public at large.

We cannot have radiated subscription television and cable television at the same time. We would say that a much more practical approach is first to introduce radiated subscription television and delay the introduction of cable television. We should delay it also for the very good reason, as Senator Button pointed out, that there is a great danger that the technology will overtake the existing co-axial cable approach that would have to be used if cable television were introduced at the moment. Fibre optics is the technology of the future. There is no doubt that within some years, although I query whether it will become common as quickly as Senator Button indicated, optic fibre technology will be with us, and if in five or 10 years time cable television were considered viable and needed to be introduced into our major cities at that time no doubt we would have a much more modern approach to its introduction so far as technology is concerned. For all these various reasons we feel very strongly as a party that the introduction of cable television should certainly be delayed but that it is reasonable for the matter to be kept under continual review.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Energy Use, Distribution and Conservation in the Australian Capital Territory: Government Response

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by Senator Robertson:
That the Senate take note of the paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to two comments in the Government's response. The inquiry was first undertaken in the previous Parliament and was again referred to the Committee by this Parliament. The Commonwealth inquired into petrol prices and petrol shortages in the Australian Capital Territory because at that time we were suffering from petrol shortages. Perhaps it is a little ironic that the situation exists again at present. As a result of discussions between the then Chairman of the Committee, the late Senator John Knight, and the then Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Ellicott, the terms of reference of the Committee were extended to inquire more broadly into the matter of energy.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer to the Government's response in relation to petrol prices. Paragraph 97 of the report refers to the fact that in December 1980 the difference between Sydney and Canberra in the price of petrol was 4c a litre, the price being higher in Canberra. There was concern also about the price differential between Canberra and Queanbeyan. The oil companies gave varying explanations as to why prices were higher in Canberra. These explanations included matters such as the cost of transport. Of course, the cost of transport to Canberra is not dissimilar to that of Queanbeyan. One reason given for the difference of 2c a litre between Canberra and Queanbeyan was the fixed price of petrol in New South Wales. But that still left a differential of 2c a litre which the oil companies were not able to explain adequately to the satisfaction of the Committee which held the inquiry.

I am concerned about the apparent discrimination which exists concerning the price at which petrol is sold on a wholesale basis at the refineries. I believe the discrimination acts against the service stations which sell oil and petrol in the Australian Capital Territory. There has been no reasonable explanation from the oil companies as to their attitude in relation to the wholesale pricing of petrol. I would like to see the companies remove the discriminatory wholesale pricing arrangement and for them to give a better explanation as to why petrol costs so much more in Canberra than it does elsewhere. The real issue concerns the wholesale pricing of petrol. That concern is expressed in recommendation 6 of the Government's recommendations.

Recommendation 8 referred to the need to upgrade the railway link to Canberra, and the need for a service to enable people to travel more cheaply and to enable a development of the private sector in Canberra. A more viable rail service is required. The Government in its response said that the whole question of rail access to Canberra would be covered in the context of general proposals for upgrading transport links to the Australian Capital Territory. Whilst that is very encouraging it does not really tell us a great deal about when this will occur and the extent to which it is diligently being pursued. Without going into all the aspects of access to Canberra at this stage I would confine my comments to the report which specifically referred at paragraphs 139 and 140 to rail travel and quoted from a submission of the National Capital Development Commission. The report stated:
Freight movement to and within the ACT is performed mainly by truck transport- except for some specialised bulk commodities. It would be possible to make substantial economies . . .

The report referred in part to the need for rail transport in that regard. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard part of a submission of the Canberra Association for Regional Development. That Association has been working very hard towards developing the private sector in Canberra. It prepared a document entitled 'Regional Transport Communications'. Part of that document dealt with rail transport. I seek leave to have incorporated pages 8 and 9 of that document .
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
CARD

PROCTEXT.PARA: Submission
Rail
6.1 The two main suggestions considered by CARD were:
upgrading of line, rollingstock and service on the existing link through Queanbeyan to Canberra.
the possible re-alignment of the main Sydney/Melbourne line with a 'T' spur to North Canberra with a later joining up with the existing Queanbeyan link.
6.2 As with road communications, State/Federal/Territorial parochialism was evident in attitudes to the provision of improved facilities and services for the existing rail link.

6.3 The existing arrangement, facilities and service are quite inadequate and it is difficult to imagine how anyone could seriously consider rail as other than a marginal contributor to transport communication in the Canberra/Queanbeyan area without major changes.
'T' Link:
6.4 The most imaginative solution as far as Canberra passenger traffic is concerned is the proposed 'T' link to the north.

6.5 The Report by the National Committee of Railway Engineering to the Institution of Engineers, Australia, as a National Engineering Project for the Australian Bi-centennial summarizes the whole situation admirably:

''. . . the existing rail link to the National Capital is over a branch of a branch; it is heavily graded, tortuously curved and so roundabout that it is quite impracticable for Melbourne traffic (even a night sleeping car service was withdrawn many years ago). If the National Capital is to perform its function properly, first class transport links with other Australian cities are essential and overdue. In terms of rail links, neither the National Capital nor the State Capital cities to which it is connected should have to suffer the inadequacy of a branch of a branch line.

. . . in contrast, the new T-line would bring the main Hume Railway within 45km of Canberra via a similarly graded and curved 160 km/h single-track spur. A passenger terminus for the diesel highspeed trains is envisaged at North Canberra in the vicinity of the showground.

. . . the inter-city bus system should desirably be linked with the proposed new terminus, from which spur lines could eventually give freight access to industrial areas such as Mitchell and Fyshwick.''

6.6 It is quite clear that the development of the 'T' link would mean the passenger rail service to Sydney would be shortened to approximately 3 hours and the service to Melbourne approximately 6 1/2 hours. This would make rail quite competitive with any other means of transport for most travellers.

6.7 If the 'T' line solution is accepted as the preferred option, the commitment to and planning of a proper connection to the existing Kingston/Fyshwick/ Queanbeyan line would be most important to provide the link to towns south of Queanbeyan and ensure existing and proposed freight terminals in South Canberra and Queanbeyan are properly utilized.

6.8 As with the work on Air transport, there were a number of immediate issues which arose during CARD's investigation on Rail. The most interesting was the XPT train. 6.9 As with Road finance CARD sees a need for the Federal Government to accept its Territorial responsibilities. CARD therefore believes that the Federal Government should contribute to the improvement to the existing link by providing funding for both line improvement and rolling stock.

6.10 There appears justification for the provision of two XPT trains on the Sydney/Queanbeyan/Canberra link as a properly scheduled and administered service is necessary if realistic patronage is to be built up.
6.11 Rail Recommendations:
urgent consideration of the 'T' link suggestion, with the importance of the link to existing services highlighted.
re-arrange financial arrangements between NSW/ Federal Governments to allow proper Territorial responsibility to be accepted on behalf of A.C.T.
review of all freight rate and administrative arrangements in respect of the ' Border problem' to streamline administration and allow the existing service to be fully integrated into the NSW system.
provision of co-operative funding to ensure a two XPT train service availability-this includes the rolling stock and line upgrading.

TALK.START.PARA: —The rail contact with Canberra is significant. I rely on that document. I commend the CARD document in total but in particular with respect to rail transport. I hope that the recommendation, which as I said is fine as far as it goes, is dealt with as a matter of considerable importance to this community.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report is the epitaph of the Legislative Drafting Institute which was a victim of the murderous ravages of the razor gang . It is a sad occasion, essentially for the reasons I spelled out in a speech in this place on 10 June 1981 when the decision was announced. I do not propose to repeat the detail of what was said there, save only to say that I think that for a relatively small annual cost the Legislative Drafting Institute was developing a very great potential not only for drafting skills and the drafting profession in Australia but also as a vehicle for aid by Australia to overseas countries, aid which stood up very well in cost benefit terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The main function of the Drafting Institute since its establishment in 1975 has not been to train legal draftsmen-those who put our statutes and regulations together in Australia-because within this country that training is still largely done by way of an apprenticeship system, or a master and pupil system, within the respective offices of the Parliamentary Counsel. Rather the primary object of the Institute has been to train each year a dozen or so students brought from a variety of overseas countries in Asia, the Pacific area, the Caribbean and Africa. In fact, such courses were conducted every year from 1975 to 1981 with the exception of 1976. In all some 56 students from 25 countries have attended the Institute's courses. Very small sums have been involved-just a few hundred thousand dollars in toto-over the entire period. It does seem to be an absurd example of the Government cutting off its nose to spite its face in this desperate desire to economise or to take functions out of the public sector.

The only other point I make about the report is that it was prepared pursuant to section 215 of the razor gang legislation which was more formally entitled the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981. In particular, the obligation imposed by that section upon the Attorney-General, being the responsible Minister, caused the report to be prepared as soon as practicable after the commencing day, the commencing day for this purpose being 9 December 1981. The point I make is that it has taken nine months to produce the present report which consists of exactly one page plus financial statments dealing with receipts and payments totalling for the period in question-the last months of the existence of the Institute from 1 July through to 8 December 1981-some $146, 000. SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to confine my remarks to one of the three papers which we have before us, that is, the one which deals with South Australia. Senators from Queensland and Tasmania are present in the chamber and I guess that they will rise and address their remarks to these papers if they want to talk about how the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act 1978 applies to their respective States. However, I am more concerned about South Australia. I notice that the supplementary agreement amends clause 10 of the principal agreement by omitting the words 'Adelaide water supply and treatment' and substituting the words 'water treatment and supply'. I guess that the purpose of the amendment to the agreement is to enable money provided by the Commonwealth to be used for the construction of a filtration plant near Morgan to supply the towns of Port Pirie, Port Augusta, Whyalla and Woomera.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not be very long in what I have to say. I point out that it took an election of the Whitlam Labor Government for something to be done about water treatment in South Australia. An agreement was reached between the Dunstan State Government and the Whitlam Federal Government to give a better water quality to the residents of Adelaide which is something that had been needed for many years . It was at our behest that the filtration plants were brought into being. I am a little disappointed that it has taken so long for all of the treatment plants to be completed. My colleague Senator Elstob said to me a while ago that he was wondering from where we would get the water if the present drought does not break very soon and particularly if we are not able to get more water from the Snowy Mountains. He wondered whether there would be any water to put through the treatment plants. Politicians cannot do anything to make it rain. Perhaps one day scientists will be able to do so but then I suppose they will be faced with the problem of stopping it because we have too much.

I am pleased that the agreement is still being carried out. I notice that the agreement is the subject of the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act 1978-Act No. 5 of 1978-which was assented to in March of that year. Of course at that time we still had a Labor Government in South Australia. Of course, as we all know, we will have another Labor Government in South Australia in March 1983. When the agreement comes up for amendment again it is quite possible it will be renegotiated by Federal and State Labor governments. We will have a change of government as soon as a Federal election is held and that is more evident as each day goes by in view of the way in which this Government is mismanaging the country. However, now that this Act is being amended, I hope that the present South Australian Liberal Government will get on with the job and stop a lot of the pussy-footing that we see. A lot of hot air comes out of the mouths of the Premier of South Australia and particularly Mr Arnold about what should be done to give us better water quality. Honourable senators well know that this has been a matter of great debate in this Parliament.

We know, of course, that the new River Murray Waters Agreement has been signed. I asked a question the other day about when we were going to see the agreement tabled in the Parliament. Senator Carrick, the Minister responsible, assured me that it should not be too long before that the new agreement is tabled in the Parliament. I hope that, when this is done, we will see some better quality water coming over the border into South Australia. I am reminded that the water that came into South Australia last year because of the low flow of the Darling River was the best quality water we have had for years. That water came out of the Murray.

Ministers may say-and Mr Arnold in particular has said so in recent times for political purposes-that the New South Wales Government was stealing South Australia's water. That is quite an erroneous statement because it is not so. South Australia was getting its fair share of water under that existing agreement. When the agreement was entered into to construct the Dartmouth dam, an ex-senator of this place who was then the Premier of South Australia never saw fit to have anything inserted in that agreement as to quality. All he was concerned about was quantity. We get, and we always have, our fair share of water. Most years we received more than our entitlement. However, we should be concerned that there will be a low flow in the river before the summer ends. We are already told that the mouth of the Murray is again silting in and the Murray will, as in recent years, again become just a pond. We cannot afford to open the mouth of the Murray by letting the water out because we would be letting good water go out to sea just to keep the Murray open. I think that this would be a tragedy for all people who use the Murray.

One concern that has been expressed to me about the cost of constructing this filtration plant at Morgan is that a lot of water that will be filtered will be used for stock. That will be a waste of good filtered water. Neither the people of Murray Bridge, where I live, nor the people of Renmark, Berri, Barmera, Loxton and Waikerie get filtered water. They get their water straight out of the river and, although in some cases it is chlorinated, it is not filtered. The purpose of this amendment to the agreement is to allow money to be expended on the filtration plant at or near Morgan. However, when the plant is constructed a lot of the water that is filtered will be used for irrigating pastures or watering stock. I do not know how much research was carried out to see whether the filtration plant could not have been installed closer to the main centres of use-that is Port Pirie, Port Augusta and Whyalla. But we cannot do anything about this now because the Agreement has been signed and the Government of South Australia has made the decision-I am not quibbling about it-to construct the filtration plant at or near Morgan. I will not seek leave to continue my remarks because my State colleague Senator Jessop is almost certain to want to speak on this agreement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also comment on the National Waters Resources (Financial Assistance) Act. Unlike Senator McLaren I refer to Queensland also because I think in the overall context of our consideration of water resources in Australia we cannot ignore the fact that it is estimated that 22 per cent of the water that flows into the Murray each year comes from Queensland. Therefore, I do not think we can ignore that important aspect. It highlights my concern that a more aggressive national approach ought to be taken with respect to this important resource. I join Senator McLaren in welcoming this Act as it applies to South Australia. I lived at Port Augusta and know what the quality of the water happened to be in that area. I drank it for 15 1/2 years and sometimes I could hardly see through the glass of water that I was trying to drink. That happened frequently.

SPEECH.PARA: This filtration system, extended to that part of South Australia, will be most welcome. That part of South Australia has also had problems with respect to amoebic meningitis. I know that the filtration is not a cure-all for that but at least it does enable the chlorination technology to be more effective. I think that should be welcomed also. I commend the previous State Labor Government on its initiative in introducing water filtration in South Australia. But I also think we should pay some compliment to the present State Government, which has seen the significance and importance of extending this system. I believe that the South Australian Government, in its national approach to water in Australia, ought to be commended because to my knowledge it is the first government that has supported the concept of a national approach. I think that point ought to be made and credit ought to be given to Peter Arnold who, as Minister for Water Resources in South Australia, has certainly come to grips with the problem and is giving a great amount of encouragement to the continuation of the work that was started many years ago.

I join in welcoming this move and hope that the Federal Government will continue with the objective of establishing a national water resources system in Australia so that we can look after this important resource. I believe that, unless we do so by about the year 2019 or 2020, our water resources will be fully committed. Unless we do something more to examine the question of our artesian resource and to ensure that we do not mine the water, as is happening in some parts of the world, I think we will be in trouble and our national development program will slow down beyond that time, if not stop altogether.
