TALK.START.PARA: —This report gives little cause for optimism about the role and functions of the Trade Practices Commission under the present Government. The performance of the Government in winding back over a period the resources and capacity of the Commission to do the job which it was originally set up to do reminds one very much of the performance of the Government in relation to the whole tax avoidance and evasion area. It is an atmosphere in which punches are being pulled, in which there is much noise but little substance to back it up and little willingness to devote the kind of resources which are necessary if a regulatory body such as this is to be a useful and viable organisation. One suspects that the Government has been nobbled by business in this respect. It is not prepared to withdraw entirely from the trade practices regulation area because of the undoubted public relations difficulties in doing that. It has chosen instead to do it by stealth, leaving behind what is unfortunately looking more and more like an impotent shell.

SPEECH.PARA: It is now eight years since the Murphy Trade Practices Act was introduced, changing as it did the face of restrictive trade practices and consumer protection law in this country. The retreat from the operation of the Commission as it was originally intended has been evident in two major respects. One is the steady clawback in the funding made available to the organisation. There is another 10 per cent real reduction evident in the staffing moneys available this year. The other is the way in which the most effective weapon that such a body can have-namely, the ability to litigate and to operate aggressively through the courts in relation to those breaching standards of the legislation-has also been wound back. This point was given much attention in last year's annual report, in particular in the supplementary comments of former Commissioner Pengilley, who described litigation as the essence of the credibility of the Trade Practices Act and pointed to the way in which an Act such as this is a paper tiger unless it is enforced-of course, that might be said about a number of areas of law that have been the subject of active discussion recently-and how the credibility of the legislation is fading fast as a result of the failure to follow through.

The figures in this report, which were the subject of some discussion by Estimates Committee A yesterday, are really quite extraordinary. Out of some 22, 000 complaints, something like only four consumer protection cases were taken to court by the Commission in 1981-82. Out of something like 2,7000 complaints made to the Commission only one restrictive trade practices case was taken to court. In fact only a total of 14 cases have been taken to court over the past four years. Of course, the legislation can be used in other ways than by the Commission's initiating litigation or prosecutions. But if the Commission is to be the standard-bearer, as one would hope it would be in these areas, obviously it needs to be right in the forefront where these decisions matter most and where action matters most.

A statement was made at the Estimates Committee hearing yesterday that it is hoped that some renewed emphasis can be given this financial year to the litigation role. But looking at the budgetary allocation for legal fees, on the assumption that not all of the work can be done in-house, it is not evident that that aspiration can be satisfied from the resources now available. There is one other quick thing I want to say about litigation and that is that it may be that the resource constraint is the crucial one. Nonetheless there are some rather odd, and I would think unsatisfactory, decisions being made by the Commission when faced with requests for it to take legal action.

The one that has come most prominently to my attention is a request initiated by the Townsville regional conservation council in respect of Minatome Australia Pty Ltd, which operates the Ben Lomond uranium deposit-the exploratory work that is going on near Townsville. The conservation council has taken the position, based on reasonable evidence, that the Minatome corporation has in fact been guilty of false and misleading advertising within the meaning of the Trade Practices Act and action has been taken accordingly to try to get the Trade Practices Commission to prosecute for that breach. The reply that has been given by the Commission to that request, and indeed to myself, having made some representations on behalf of the conservation council, seems to me to reflect a rather curious appreciation of the Commission's role. The exercise is rejected by the Commission on two grounds, both relating to the proper terms of reference for the Commission's approach to the complaint.

The Commission has rejected the complaint for reasons which I think are unsatisfactory in two ways. The first way they are unsatisfactory-I do not have the time to go into this in any detail-is that Mr Bannerman, speaking on behalf of the Commission, has seen or defined the central issue at stake in the proposed litigation as the question of the seriousness of any risk to the water supply of Townsville flowing from the Ben Lomond operations. However, the issue which I think is appropriate for the Commission to draw its attention to is not the substantive merits underlying the particular application but rather the much more immediate legal question as to whether the Minatome corporation has engaged in misleading or deceptive conduct or advertising in relation to the work it is doing and the implications of that work.

The second ground for concern about the Commission's response is its assertion that it would not be appropriate for the Commission to bring proceedings at public expense as this would simply involve applying counter-pressure in a battle between a conservation council and a corporation, and that such a political exercise could be better engaged in by the Council's making appropriate representations to the Queensland Government, the likely outcome of which we can readily anticipate.

My point, and indeed that made by the Conservation Council, is that this sort of response would seem to misconceive the role of the Commission in relation to complaints of this kind. It may be that the response of Mr Bannerman and the Commission is perfectly understandable given the constraints of scarce resources and their simply having to find grounds, any grounds, however irrelevant to the basic purposes of the Act as originally framed, to justify their failure to take action to intervene and to initiate prosecutions in this area. But if that is so and if, as I believe, spurious grounds are being taken to justify non-action of this kind that is because of a resource constraint, that is but another demonstration of the unhappy condition to which the Commission has been reduced by the Government's failure to fund.

My final point relates to a number of recommendations in the report as to changes to the legislation to cope with various suggestions for change that have been made or have emerged from the experience of the Commission. One matter that again deserves more attention than I can give it during these brief remarks is the time constraint which presently exists on prosecutions launched by the Commission. Under section 21 (1) of the Commonwealth Crimes Act, where no term of imprisonment is specified for the particular offence, a prosecution may be commenced only within a specified period-six months or 12 months as the case may be. The difficulty, as has been apparent in recent times, is that the removal of gaol terms from the kinds of penalties that may be imposed for breaches of the Trade Practices Act has had the incidental effect of requiring all classes of prosecution to be commenced within 12 months of the facts, to which the events gave rise, occurring.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few words on the Trade Practices Commission report because it is a tragedy that, upon the Parliament receiving a report of this nature, honourable senators should be limited to making a short 10-minute contribution concerning it. The Trade Practices Act came into force eight years ago, almost to the day. It had as its purpose strengthening the competitiveness of private enterprise at the various levels of production and distribution. It was also designed, in that process, to strengthen the position of, and benefit, consumers and deal with unethical practices that had been brought to the attention of the Parliament. In other words, the purpose of the legislation was to show that there was an ugly face to business and that legislative action was required to remedy the position.

SPEECH.PARA: However, this Government, largely as a result of the activities of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions, or razor gang, has seen fit to reduce the effectiveness of this organisation to an alarming degree. That is seen in what has happened to its staff ceiling since July 1975. There has since been an effective reduction, in the 226 personnel employed by the Commission, of 25 per cent, to a figure of 161. The Government, in denying the Commission staff and financial resources, in making its effective work subject to the day-to-day direction of the Minister, and in making ministerial rearrangements that took place earlier this year-in the course of which the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs was abolished and its functions transferred to the Attorney- General's Department-gives a clear indication of its lack of concern. Now the Commonwealth Government is the only government in Australia that has not an active consumer affairs department such as is present in all of the States. An attempt is made to suggest that these matters should be dealt with by State administrations. Also, the razor gang abolished the Trade Practices Consultative Committee, which performed a very important function in not only protecting the interests of consumers but also providing consultation and advice for the important small business and primary industry sections of the economy.

A further indication of the downgrading of the work of the Commission is given by the Government's action in placing it under the day-to-day attention of the Minister and reducing its effective role of monitoring advertising and business practices, matters clearly requiring Commonwealth jurisdiction. The report also refers with some trepidation to the freedom of information legislation. I can only hope that the Commission remains true to its commitment to give liberal effect of the Parliament's policy of invoking to the least possible extent the exemptions in the freedom of information legislation. The report continues at some length to explain the effects of the razor gang's actions on consumer protection and what this has done to render ineffective that function of the Commission. The report continues:
One effect of the direction-
That is, of the Minister-

is the inability of the TPC to take the first initiative in investigation, being dependent instead on a matter being brought to its attention by an external source. This has for example prevented the TPC from monitoring national advertising to see whether, on its face, it contravenes the Act or requires some investigation.

Since the Ministerial Direction the TPC has required, until recently, that each complaint be submitted to it by staff for approval to carry out any investigation at all, thus exercising very tight control . . . This very tight control has meant that some matters have necessarily come to the TPC inadequately developed and with too little information. In addition contact with the company complained of may itself result in resolution of the complaint. The TPC has now delegated to senior staff the power to seek the company's comments on the complaint.

I invite honourable senators to look at the complaints that are listed. They concern sales of motor vehicles such as we read of in the popular Press. Also, there have been a number of false advertisements relating to fuel saving devices . We live in a time when some consciousness is developing about the necessity to conserve fuel, so there have been unscrupulous practices by manufacturers designed to fool purchasers. Again, we have read in the popular Press of a number of cases of airline overbookings and what distress that has caused airline travellers. Reference is in the report also to a number of false and misleading advertisements about residential land. People save for the purpose of providing themselves with accommodation only to find that they are caught by land sharks. In the report that is repeatedly brought to the attention of the Parliament.

The report also contains evidence of retail malpractices on the part of even such prominent companies as Waltons Ltd, which on two occasions has been fined for misleading advertising in respect of furniture.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 6.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In general the Australian Broadcasting Commission provides an excellent news service for Australian people. However, on rare occasions it falls short of providing this excellent service and when this happens it should be mildly chastised. I intend to issue a rebuke to the ABC because of the matter I am raising this evening. On the noon radio news service on 10 September, last Friday, the following news item was issued by the ABC:

SPEECH.PARA: The ACT is challenging Darwin's claim to have the highest beer consumption in Australia, but from a totally different angle. Canberrans are the heaviest consumers of milk in Australia. According to figures from the milk authority they down 120.2 litres a year, compared to the Australian average of 107.5. The figures for the financial year for 81/82 show a steadily increasing demand for milk in the ACT compared with the 1980/81 sales figure of 113 litres a head, perhaps surprisingly tropical Queensland has the second biggest milk consumption average of 116.7 litres a head and Victoria is third with 115.1 litres.

That is a fairly straightforward news item. Perhaps it is not as exciting as excerpts from the report of the Costigan Royal Commission into the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union, but it is straightforward nonetheless. However, an hour later the story was changed a little. This was the item read by the newscaster on the 1 p.m. ABC radio news service:

In the category of 'we're not too sure what it means' comes the news that people in Canberra are the heaviest consumers of milk in Australia. According to figures from the milk authority, Canberra's average consumption per person is 120 litres a year, compared to the national average of 107. Canberra has a big population of public servants.

If the newscaster was not too sure what it meant I am not too sure what the newscaster meant by that particular comment. What does it mean? Does it mean that public servants drink a lot of milk because they have endless cups of tea? Perhaps it refers to the fat cats in the Public Service who need plenty of milk. I am not sure what was meant by that news item. It is not the standard of news reporting that we normally associate with the ABC. If the ABC wants a second- rate reputation that is the way to go about it. There is a more likely explanation of why the milk consumption in the Australian Capital Territory is higher than the national average. That explanation is that Canberra has a young population. If it has a younger population than the national average it might be that such a population has a high milk consumption.

I had a look at some of the figures for the population distribution in the Australian Capital Territory by age and I noted that the under five years age group comprises 9.3 per cent of the Territory's population. This compares with the Australian average of 7.6 per cent. So in general there is a younger population, according to figures on that age group, in the Australian Capital Territory. So it will not be thought that I picked just one age group I refer to two other groups. The under 10 years age group comprises 19.5 per cent of the population of the Australian Capital Territory compared with the Australian average of 16.1 per cent. The under 16 years group comprises 30.9 per cent of the population of the Australian Capital Territory, compared with the Australian average of 26.6 per cent. So in general it appears that the Territory population is younger than the Australian average. That could explain why milk consumption in the Australian Capital Territory is higher than the Australian average. It is probably not the only explanation but it is certainly a better explanation than the ironic humour attempted by the ABC.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, upon notice, on 10 March 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What consultants or outside agencies, have been engaged by the Special Broadcasting Service, or the Department of Communications to assess in any way the audience response to Channel 0/28, the multicultural broadcasting service, and if any such assessments have been made, what information has been obtained on audience response.
(2) Are theses results available to the public.
(3) Has the Institute of Multicultural Affairs had any involvement in such assessments, and does it continue to have any involvement.

(4) Does the Special Broadcasting Service subscribe to the McNair-Anderson survey; if so, will the Minister set out in the answer the principal survey result which he considers to be of significance, for each rating period since the service went to air.
(5) Are (a) the McNair-Anderson survey results, and (b) any other survey results, an adequate and accurate assessment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question, provided by the Special Broadcasting Service:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) A number of research companies have been engaged by the Special Broadcasting Service to obtain preliminary assessments of the multicultural television service. These companies were: McNair Anderson Associates Pty Ltd, Sydney; Inview Market Research, Melbourne; Tavistock Research Centre Pty Ltd, Sydney; and Spectrum Research, Sydney. Both quantitative measurement and qualitative audience reaction studies have been carried out, together with surveys of reception difficulties in Sydney. A comprehensive study to follow the 15 month establishment period of the service was conducted by McNair Anderson during January and February 1982. Aspects of multicultural television which were investigated include:
the level of public support for the concept of a multicultural television service;
opinions by audiences on whether multicultural television is achieving its aims ;
the size of the audience to multicultural television;
the views of audiences on the standard of programs presented;
general likes/dislikes of the service;
audience reaction to subtitled programs, etc.
(2) Most of the studies conducted have not been available to the public but a comprehensive summary of the findings of the January/February 1982 study have now been published and circulated publicly.

(3) The Institute of Multicultural Affairs conducted its own assessment survey, to which the Special Broadcasting Service has made financial contribution. Results of the survey were published in the Institute's 'Evaluation of Post Arrival Programs and Services'.

(4) Yes. The significant results from surveys to date illustrate that the most popular programs of the service are news, current affairs and feature films. A special analysis of each survey during 1981 has shown that the average number of people who view multicultural television each week is 305,000 in Sydney, and 368 ,000 in Melbourne. A special survey conducted by McNair Anderson in early 1982 ( referred to in (1) above) indicates that a total of 935,000 people viewed multicultural television in that city during the four week survey period.

Assuming a proportionate Sydney performance to the average weekly figures throughout 1981 as shown above, the Special Broadcasting Service considers that it could be estimated that approximately 1,700,000 people viewed multicultural television in Sydney and Melbourne during the four week period.

(5) (a) It is considered by the Special Broadcasting Service that there are special difficulties in measuring two of the several core audiences of multicultural television-namely, ethnic audiences of limited or no command of English, audiences in the upper income groups. It is possible that some understatement of audiences to multicultural television therefore occurs in standard industry surveys.
(b) No quantitative surveys have been carried out with other organisations, and the Special Broadcasting Service is of the opinion that comment cannot therefore be made on other survey results.

The regular station 'share' figures shown in the McNair Anderson industry reports, and frequently quoted in the Press, (usually in the order of 1.5 per cent to 2.5 per cent) are considered by the Special Broadcasting Service to be inadequate audience performance criteria for the evaluation of multicultural television, as they do not illustrate the size of the audience reached. They are used mainly by commercial stations in recognition of a need for a simple competitive index. As such, station 'share' figures illustrate comparative station performances in terms of their individual shares of total viewing time given by audiences to all television stations in each market.

The Special Broadcasting Service considers that the performance of multicultural television should also not be assessed on a quarter hour by quarter hour rating basis as required by commercial stations for advertising sales purposes. Multicultural television is able to use all quarter hours during which it is on air to achieve its multicultural aims. Its total reach of audience during the period of its transmissions is therefore of prime importance .

In this connection it is the opinion of the Special Broadcasting Service that the standard industry surveys in Melbourne throughout 1981 show an average of 17 per cent of Melbourne homes tuned in to multicultural television each week and that the recent survey in January/February 1982 indicates that this figure rises to approximately 43 per cent in Melbourne over a four week period.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Karumba

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the function of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation research facility at Karumba on the Gulf of Carpenteria before its closure in 1979.
(2) Why was this research terminated and the installation abandoned three years ago at a time when the area's prawning industry was (and is) struggling to survive.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Karumba field station was originally established to enable scientists studying the banana prawn to work there for extended periods in the wet season, which is an important phase of the prawn's life cycle.

(2) After three or four years of field work, time was needed to analyse and interpret the results and scientists left Karumba in 1979. As a result of their findings, the banana prawn catch can now be predicted each season with some confidence on the basis of rainfall records.

Field work on norther prawns resumed in 1981, but the emphasis is now on the tiger prawn, which has become the principal component of the catch. Karumba is well away from the main tiger prawn area, and some of its buildings are being used to establish a new field station at Groote Eylandt, which is the centre of the tiger prawn industry. CSIRO is puting increased effort into prawn research, with support from the Fishing Industry Research Trust Account.
Struggles to survive in the northern prawn industry are largely due to economic factors including fuel and operating cost increases, not to a decline in total catch.
